urn:contentItem:5S5X-J7H1-JBHT-D42X-00000-00French President Arrives in the U.S. Ahead of Trump's First State Dinner; North Korea to Suspend Nuke Tests; Earnings in Focus this Week; Pompeo Confirmation Battle; Nunes: No Intel Found; Five Ships Carrying U.S. Sorghum Changes Course in Ocean after China Announced Massive Tariffs; Socialism Goes Mainstream2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrench President Arrives in the U.S. Ahead of Trump's First State Dinner; North Korea to Suspend Nuke Tests; Earnings in Focus this Week; Pompeo Confirmation Battle; Nunes: No Intel Found; Five Ships Carrying U.S. Sorghum Changes Course in Ocean after China Announced Massive Tariffs; Socialism Goes MainstreamLanhamFULL TEXT

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Here is Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan. He will take you to the next hour.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Every day is a busy day, Charles. Thank you very much.

PAYNE: All right.

WEBSTER: Breaking right now, French President Emmanuel Macron just landing at Joint Base Andrews as he begins a three-day state visit hosted by President Trump. We're also keeping an eye on your money, of course, as U.S. Treasury yields creep towards three percent, which is sparking new fears of a bear market on Wall Street. We shall see.

Good afternoon, everybody, and welcome. I'm Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan and on now to THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT.

President Trump and Macron will look to strengthen their, well, bromance if you like as both men have a lot riding on this week's visit where trade and the Iran nuclear deal are set to dominate the agenda. I'll be discussing this with former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee straight ahead.

Plus, of course, North Korea says it will suspend all nuclear tests ahead of its historic summit with South Korea. President Trump tweeting this, "We are a long way from conclusion on North Korea, maybe things will work out, and maybe they won't. Only time will tell." We have more on that coming up.

Lots to talk about. But, first, French President Emmanuel Macron as we say just landing on American soil, now is making his way to Washington to meet with President Trump. Do we have Fox -- do we have -- he's good. We have Fox News's Doug McKelway. He's at the White House with more on the big state visit.

Doug.

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Ashley. President Macron touched down at Joint Base Andrews just within the past hour. And his motorcade as we speak is just pulled up to Blair House about a block away he and the First Lady of France will stay there for the next couple of hours before they come here to the White House, board a helicopter with the first couple of the United States for a trip across the Potomac River where they will dine at the George Washington's Mount Vernon tonight before the first state dinner of the Trump administration which takes place here at the White House tomorrow.

These two get along famously as best as we can tell that they came evidently as early as last summer when President Trump went to Paris to enjoy Bastille Day, and came away from that meeting, having a very close personal relationship with Mr. Macron. He also came away from that meeting suggesting we have a military parade here in the United States. That is not to say that they're not considerable differences between the two gentlemen.

May 12th, for example, is a deadline for Mr. Trump to decide whether to lift sanctions on Iran. The press secretary was asked about that just in the briefing a few moments ago, which is now underway. Here is what she had to say, Sarah Huckabee Sanders.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: But what you do have are two leaders who have a great deal of respect for one another, who have a great friendship. Certainly, both have a great deal of interests in doing what is best for their country, but being able to have very open and candid conversations because of the relationship not only that the leaders have built, but that has existed between the two countries long before either of these individuals arrived on the scene. And we're going to continue that relationship. But I think we can expect this to be a very productive and very positive state visit for both countries.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: She added that she does not want to get ahead of any discussions that two might have before they actually occur. Macron, however, does believes that it would be a bad decision to get out of the Iran nuclear deal. Here's what he had to say this weekend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, PRESIDENT OF FRANCE: Is this agreement perfect and this JCPOA perfect thing for our relationship with Iran? No. But for nuclear, what do you have as a better option? I don't see it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: And May 1st is another important deadline, a time for Mr. Trump to decide whether he wants to impose tariffs on the European Union for its importation of steel and aluminum. Again, Mr. Macron thinks that would be a bad idea for Mr. Trump to do.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MACRON: You cannot make a trade your allies. I'm very -- I'm an easy guy. I'm very simple. I'm straight forward.

It's too complicated if you make war against everybody. You make trade war against China, trade war against Europe, war in Syria, war against Iran. Come on. It doesn't work. You need allies. We are the ally.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: The First Lady coming out of the shadows a little bit for this state dinner tonight. She is apparently behind all of the minute planning of this first state dinner coming tomorrow night. The first state dinner of the Trump administration.

Ashley, back to you.

WEBSTER: It's going to be quite an affair. Doug McKelway at the White House. Doug, thank you very much.

MCKELWAY: My pleasure.

WEBSTER: Joining me now to talk about that and other issues, FormerArkansas Governor Mike Huckabee. Great to see you, Governor.

You know what politics can makes for strange bedfellows, and here we have maybe Mr. Trump's lone ally in Europe right now because he's had a public spat with Theresa May and the U.K. And here we have Emmanuel Macron, who by all accounts is a political outsider who also managed to outwit the political establishment in France. So maybe it's not so strange that these two individuals kind of get along?

MIKE HUCKABEE (R), FORMER ARKANSAS GOVERNOR: Well, I think a lot of it has to do with what you just mentioned. They're both outsiders, but they're also very plain-spoken people. And they're honest with each other. The President likes that. He really does.

For all those who think that he wants to be surrounded by yes men, they don't know him very well. He doesn't like to be ridiculed in public but he does not mind having people in the meetings with him speak their mind. Clearly, President Macron is able, willing to do that. They have very frank and open discussions.

And the good thing is, look at this. I think it's the best relationship we've seen with France in many years.

WEBSTER: Yes.

HUCKABEE: And we didn't even have to bring James Taylor in to sing for it.

WEBSTER: I love the sarcasm. It's an effective form of wit despite what Stuart Varney says. OK. So, look, you know they're going to be talking, Governor, about, you know, militarily ironically.

France has been right with the U.S., both against ISIS and in Syria. But then we have the nuke deal with Iran. We have trade. We have climate change.

Can they get any common ground? Because I don't think the President is going to say, "He's kind of hinted yes, OK, maybe we can get back into the Paris climate accord." I don't see that happening. And with regard to the Iran nuke deal, we heard Macron speaking this weekend. It doesn't feel like they're going to get any common ground there.

HUCKABEE: They maybe not, Ashley. But I think that there is a likelihood that there will be some compromise on both parties to bring something to the table that works. But the President has been very clear. He's President of the United States.

He doesn't capitulate to any other country. He does what's best for America. And he expects every other world leader to do the exact same thing for their country.

But if he can be convinced whether it's by Macron or one of the others that this is really in the best interests of the United States I think he is open to it. But I'll be very clear to say, if it's not in the best interests of the United States he's not interested at all. This President is not in simply trying to be popular with world leaders. He wants to be effective in making sure that he takes care of America.

WEBSTER: Absolutely true. OK, we're gong to completely change gears. Now I want to ask you about this one. Canadian country singer Shania Twain issuing an apology after getting a lot of backlash for saying she would have voted for Donald Trump in the 2016 election.

I mean, how could she say such a thing? What are your thoughts?

HUCKABEE: It's so sad that the left refuses to allow anyone to speak his or her mind without being just pilloried and excoriated unless they agree with the left of center viewpoint that they hold. This is the most intolerant bunch of people I've ever seen in my life, Ashley, and this is a great example.

You know, it's sad that Shania Twain felt like she had to apologize, but the backlash that she got for simply expressing an opinion, why can't she do that? She ought to be able to. Tragic day.

WEBSTER: Yes, exactly. We've seen it, you know, certainly coming out of Hollywood in the movie business. No different, I guess, in the music business as well.

HUCKABEE: Too bad and it's unfortunate. We need to be able to have the kind of honest discussions that we're seeing between the French and American President where we don't always agree but we do it respectfully.

WEBSTER: Very well-said. Governor Huckabee, thank you so much for joining us today. I really appreciate it.

HUCKABEE: Thanks.

WEBSTER: All right. Let's take a look at these markets for you. Stocks just slightly lower as Wall Street kicks off its biggest week for corporate earnings. The Dow off 57 points, and we start lows earnings today with Google after the closing bell today, or Alphabet, the parent company.

Let's get down to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange where our own Nicole Petallides has the latest. Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Hey, good afternoon, Ashley. So, as you noted, we're watching for Google after the bell. We're taking a look at the broader market right now, and you do see all down arrows with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down about 64 points after some choppy trading, down volume, slightly ahead of up volume. And the Dow, the NASDAQ and the S&P all lower today, but for the month, in the green.

Interestingly enough, we've seen oil pulling just slightly higher now after having being down. But the dollar and Treasury yields have been a big story, taking a look at 10-year Treasury, which on Friday was settling at highest levels since January 2014.

Look at this, getting closer to that very psychological level of three percent. Two point ninety-eight percent right now for the 10-year bond yield. Of course, as that moves higher we'll watch for that.

Taking a look at the tech earnings, I want to get to that quickly. AlphabetGoogle is slightly lower. Facebook, Amazon, Intel, Microsoft, all of these this week, it is going to be a huge week for tech earnings. And I spoke with Joel Kulina over at Wedbush and he basically said, clearly, large cap tech has taking somewhat of a hit. But most of the investors will be looking at these, looking at the capital return announcements on all of them.

And, of course, regulatory overhang for the names, such as Facebook and Google. They gave me a lot on each one of them. We'll break it down throughout each of the hits, but we'll see all down arrows right now, Google after the bell. We'll have to see it here.

Back to you.

WEBSTER: Another busy week for you, Nicole. Thank you so much. Appreciate it. Nicole, make sure to watch "After the Bell," at 4:00 p.m. Eastern today for the latest earnings report from Alphabet/Google right here on Fox Business.

All right. Coming up, we'll have more on these markets as, yes, as Nicole said the 10-year Treasury yield is nearing at magical three percent. Is it magical or is it a nightmare? We'll find out.

Plus, new questions about the Russia investigation. House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes revealing that there was no official intelligence used to start that probe into the Trump campaign. We'll have the intel later in the show.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: A lot of breaking news to bring you right now. Let's begin with news from the Nashville Police Department, which says the suspect in the Waffle House shooting there has been taken into custody just moments ago. So that's an update there.

Meanwhile, north of the border, several people in Toronto had been hurt after a white van reportedly plowed into a group of pedestrians. The extent of injuries on whether it was intentional or an accident is still not known. We're told that at least eight people are said to have been hit by that white van. Of course, we'll keep monitoring all of the stories and bring you the very latest updates as they become available.

Let's get back to politics. Democratic Senator Joe Manchin announcing he supports CIA Director Mike Pompeo to be the next Secretary of State, tweeting this. "After meeting with Mike Pompeo, discussing his foreign policy perspectives and considering his distinguished time as CIA Director and his exemplary career in public service, I will vote to confirm Mike Pompeo to be our next Secretary of State."

Now Manchin is the second Democrat to support Pompeo's nomination, possibly giving him some momentum ahead of a showdown vote in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. That panel, though, poised to vote against Pompeo.

Joining us now to discuss this, American Progress Action Fund Larry Korb. All right. Larry, why this unprecedented rebuke of Mike Pompeo? Is it just purely obstructionism? What's the play here?

LARRY KORB, SENIOR FELLOW, AMERICAN PROGRESS ACTION FUND: Well, I think a lot of the people, including Republican Rand Paul are concerned that his positions will reinforce President Trump's worst tendencies and they want someone who will serve, you know, as a counterweight. And I don't think Director Pompeo has helped himself by not telling the members of the committee off-line, you know, about his North Korean trip because this is theoretically acting like a Secretary of State before you get there. But, as you pointed out, he will be confirmed.

And, you know, people talk about it. People forget when Chuck Hagel, Senator Hagel went up to be Secretary of Defense under President Obama, he only got three Republican votes on the floor. So this is not unprecedented for people to use this to make another point.

WEBSTER: But you could argue, Larry, that the point that Mr. Pompeo didn't tell anyone or told the least amount of people possible is that it's a chronic place for leaking information. And there's one thing they didn't want was for that visit to Pyongyang to come out before he went there and came back. And then we could talk about it, but he didn't want that to be known to the general public. And Washington is a place for leaks.

KORB: No, but I think when he came back he should have briefed them off- line because, again, the worst thing you do -- well, I remember my own experience, if you start acting like you got the job before you are confirmed, a lot of people will not take that very well.

WEBSTER: So you do believe he'll get through the full Senate?

KORB: I think he will because you've already got, at least two Democrats.

WEBSTER: Yes.

KORB: And so, I think he will.

WEBSTER: Could it unsettle the North Korean negotiations effort? Is their timing on this pretty poor?

KORB: No, I don't think so. And I think, you know, basically, his trip was the right thing to do, or somebody should have gone, you know, to talk to the North Koreans who lay the groundwork. And today, over the weekend we've seen some public back and forth, and I think once sensible thing the administration has said is, they're not going to make any concessions just because he stopped doing what he's doing. He's going to have to start dismantling stuff before we relax the economic sanctions.

WEBSTER: And that's going to be the key elements, one, nuke, you know, dismantlement. But, first, the timetable for the sanctions comes after that, which really puts the ball in the court of North Korea. I guess the fact that we're talking is very positive, but we have to have a pretty hefty amount of skepticism when we look at this as well.

KORB: Yes. I mean the North Koreans promised several times going back to the 1990s that they're going to do something that they didn't do it. So you not only wanted to start dismantling it, you want to have intrusive inspections much like we have, for example, in Iran where they can go in and check and see that he's living up to the deal.

WEBSTER: Do you think President Trump's unconventional approach, the tweets, the "rocket man" references, all of that have kind of discombobulated Pyongyang a little bit and that's what's got us to this point?

KORB: I think the key thing was the sanctions. I give President Trump for giving much tougher sanctions than we have before because we got the international community, particularly the Chinese and Russians to go along. Now, they may have been concerned that, you know, President Trump might do something erratic.

But the fact in the matter those sanctions are starting to hurt, and that's why he has stopped this program because he has gotten as far as he wants to. He has the capability. The question is now, are you going to you limit that capability.

WEBSTER: Ten seconds, Larry. Are you confident we can get something out of this summit?

KORB: I think we can because, again, I think the sanctions are beginning to bite and I think that he recognizes that this is once in a lifetime opportunity, not only with us, but a very liberal government in South Korea.

WEBSTER: Yes. Good point. Well, we shall see, as they say. Larry Korb, thank you so much. Larry, appreciate it.

KORB: Thanks for having me.

WEBSTER: All right. Let's take a look at these markets. We're being down slightly lower on the Dow. We're off 85 points, now maybe getting a little momentum on the downside. We'll have more on the markets and what's moving them on the intel right after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: We want to get back now to that story out of Toronto as we're getting more information. The driver of a white van, a white Ryder van plowing into at least eight to 10 pedestrians on the sidewalk. That driver now in custody.

Toronto police not revealing any calls or motive behind this. Police say the van apparently jumped the curb. This is all happening as Cabinet ministers from the G7 countries are gathered in Toronto right now ahead of June summit in Quebec.

Eyewitnesses saying it appeared the driver did indeed deliberately tried to hit people on the sidewalk. But, again, we don't know what's the motive for this yet, but the suspect is in custody.

Let's get back to the markets. Stocks are at sessions lows as the 10-year Treasury yield hovers right around its highest level in four years, now closing in on three percent causing economists who worry about rising, borrowing costs.

Joining me now is MaxFund.com Founder Jonas Ferris along with Surevest Wealth Management CEO Rob Luna.

All right. Jonas, let me begin with you. Why is three percent on the 10- year such a psychological level? Surely, we can handle three percent because historically that's still really low?

JONAS FERRIS, FOUNDER, MAXFUND.COM: Historically it's low. It is less psychologically useful than like Dow 10,000 was technically meaningless and 20,000.

WEBSTER: Right.

FERRIS: It's just a price index on stocks. That's an arbitrary. The whole -- you know, you're borrowing money at these rates and you're investing money at these rates. So, like it means something to institutional investors and retail investors.

You know, people might not take a mortgage if it breaks a certain threshold in their head or a car loan. That's why you see like 3.99 percent fines in yields. This is a meaningful threshold. And a lot of buyers are coming in at three. And that's what happened for all of the last times you run up to three over the last three years.

And a lot of demands for bonds when the rate gets a little higher. It's still low historically but it's a safe yield. And, you know, the stock market is high and it's very volatile as you've seen in recent months.

So there's been a lot of independent demand that comes in around three. And maybe the government is selling hundreds of billions of dollars of debt at this level, so we're very concerned, is it going to breach three and all of a sudden it was going to panic and say, "OK, the 30-year bull market in Treasury is over and bonds is over?"

WEBSTER: Right.

FERRIS: Then we go to 3.4, four, and that's when the real panic would start.

WEBSTER: You know, Rob, I moved to the United States in 1982. It was a real steal if you got a mortgage for 16 percent. So I have a hard time panicking over this, but I get Jonas' point. It's seems, Rob, that we're trading in a range right now, especially with a perceived hawkish Fed in background just waiting to raise rates.

ROB LUNA, CEO, SUREVEST WEALTH MANAGEMENT: Yes, and that's exactly it, Ashley. I mean, we've seen that since the beginning of the year. And I really expect that to continue for the rest of the year.

You know, I've been seeing for a while the easy money is done in this market. And investors really need to change their playbook if they're going to be able to generate returns. And quite honestly, importantly, mitigate the risk in their portfolio.

You know, the idea of 60/40 buy and hold portfolio where bonds are expected to be that buffer to cushion at the downside of stocks as we've already seen this year is not working. And some of the more conservative investors are the one actually taking the brunt of the storm.

WEBSTER: Jonas, we're going to find out the latest earnings from the big tech companies this week. We kick it off after the bell today with Google. If we have a blowout performance by these big, big technology companies how much impetus does that give to the market?

FERRIS: It's helpful. We saw that with Netflix recently. But I think that -- there's still a lot of fear that the underlying business model of a Google and Facebook, which is largely based on privacy -- looking to privacy and selling it off to advertisers, is under the spotlight. And the more we learn about those behaviors, the more we're concerned that there's going to be a regulatory crackdown or there's a consumer revolt. And it's going to limit the earnings growth potential of these companies.

Even with good numbers right now, I think there's a lot -- there's enough fear baked into that side of the FANG so-called equation which is, again, largely based on selling targeted advertising and more as we learn every week, we think there's new revelation what they're doing with your data when you're not getting logged in.

WEBSTER: Right.

FERRIS: It's just absurd. So, I think that's going to keep them in it. We have not seen Apple phone sales as strong as people would like. So there's a lot of pressure in tech. And a good earnings report isn't going to take that away at this point.

It will be helpful like it was in Netflix, but at this point there's long- term fears there and that's why the three percent Treasury yield is starting to look comforting to people --

WEBSTER: Right.

FERRIS: -- in the world of maybe tech companies aren't going to grow as fast as they have.

WEBSTER: True. You know, Rob, we had an analyst on this morning on our network who said the only thing that really worries him, he feels like earnings are strong, the economy is humming along nicely, some sort of geopolitical situation could really knock it off the axis. Do you have concerns like that?

LUNA: Well, I mean, geopolitical concerns, Ashley, are always in our outlook for the markets, and something that could happen at anytime. So, yes, if you see something like that, you know, I think part of the reason we've calm down and we've had a positive month is because the rhetoric out of North Korea is kind of calmed down quite a bit and we're starting to see progress there. So, if that starts to tick back up again, if earnings don't come in that great, and you start to see this interest rates rise above three percent, those are all going to provide headwinds for investors in this market.

WEBSTER: Jonas, we'll play the what if game. What if the Democrats take back the House, does that have impact on the market? Perhaps the less business-friendly House, would that have that have an impact?

FERRIS: I don't think that's a current concern because it wouldn't lead to like tax cuts.

WEBSTER: Right.

FERRIS: You're not going to automatically have higher corporate tax rate just because there's a power change. So there would have to be such a huge swing for there anything that affect what the market liked, which was the tax package in recent years.

I think, you know, there's a positive and negative going on right now. These rates are going up because the economy is strong, partially because of tax cuts. So, it's not like it's all bad that rates are going up. The question is do they go up so fast that it's faster, or does the Fed raise rates too high and causes recession?

WEBSTER: Yes.

FERRIS: That's what kind of the fears. But, again, there's an underlying strength here that people want to invest in, which is why the stock market is still strong.

WEBSTER: Right.

FERRIS: People don't want to miss what could be an even longer bull market.

WEBSTER: So, Rob, could the tax cuts kind of counteract the rising interest rates?

LUNA: Yes, I think so. And I think that's what where going to start seeing, Ashley, out of companies as they're starting to report this quarter. And that's why expectations are so high for earnings.

But let's be careful, you know, I think Jeremy Siegel out of Lawrence talked about this quite a bit, that a lot of this is going to be front-end loaded. You're getting this accelerated depreciation in assets. But come next year when all that sworn off, if companies can't generate good top- lines growth, I think you're going to see all of this taken back.

And I think investors are pretty smart that they're starting to look at that now. So even though companies are being in these expectations, they're still a little bit skeptical if they're going to be able to continue that especially in a rising interest rate environment.

WEBSTER: You know, Jonas, it feels like we've lost the volatility that we had just weeks ago where we were up 400, down another 500. As I said to Rob earlier on, we're now in this kind of a range which I think comforts the average investor because that volatility can be very, you know, very alarming.

FERRIS: It was. We had a few like eras of that since, but it's been, you know, a pretty much non-stop, you know, bull market since early 2009. So, there's been, you know, there's the Greece problems of the debt bangs. There's always been a volatility era.

Then it seems just go away when we go on to higher things. But at this point, it does seem like we're moving more sideways then we were going to have to see that the economy can grow in spite so to say of higher rates.

WEBSTER: Right.

FERRIS: Because a lot of people also believe the opposite that rates are going up because of the tax cuts possibly in a way to counter the benefit of them. And that's where we kind of watching for and, again, it's always been the case where they raise rates too high. Thinking the economy is too hot, cause a recession. You don't want to be sitting in a high P-E stock portfolio when we go to next recession. So that's kind of the fear.

And to your original point, you know, these home prices, when you are -- they need to be have mortgages --

WEBSTER: Yes.

FERRIS: -- the home prices weren't based on having a three percent mortgage. So that's what's they've been concerned what happens when they go back to six percent, because the home prices have to go right back down to adjust to that or they're going to stay there --

WEBSTER: Very good point.

FERRIS: -- showing to the market right now.

WEBSTER: Of course, I hope we don't drop suddenly 500 points as I've just said. Anyway, Jonas and Rob, thank you so much gentlemen for --

LUNA: Thanks, Ashley.

WEBSTER: -- talking about the markets with us. Really appreciate it.

Let's get back now more on this breaking news out of Toronto as police say a van hit at least eight people on the sidewalk, but any motive unknown at this hour but we do know that the driver is in custody.

Fox News's Catherine Herridge, a native of Toronto, by the way, joins me right now with more on this story.

Catherine, what are you hearing?

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Well, we're waiting for some indication from the police as to the motivation of the suspect and the identification of the suspect. But having covered Homeland Security now for 18 years, I can tell you a number of things really stand out to me about the incident.

Number one, for those at home who are not familiar with Toronto, Young Street is the main north-south artery running through the city. It starts at Lake Ontario. And then it travels up dozens of miles to Northern Ontario. I think it may in fact be the longest street running north-south in the entire country of Canada.

And this intersection with Finch Avenue is one of the major east-west arteries. And it's also one of the major hubs for the subway system there known as the TTC, the Toronto Transit Commission.

So you have one of the major arteries in the city. You also have coupled with that, the subway system and then you also have the time of day, 1:30. This is when people are finishing up their lunch hour and heading back to work. And this area is not only a business area but it's a heavily residential area. There are a lot of large condominium complexes up in that part of Toronto with sort of what I would call smaller residential neighborhoods, older neighborhoods off to the side.

So if the individual's motivation was to inflict a maximum number of casualties, they really kind of checked all the boxes in this particular situation, you know, a major artery for traffic, vehicular and pedestrian traffic in Toronto. Also the subway system, the time of day, and based on the eyewitness reports that we're getting out of Toronto, the driver of the white van was driving north on Young Street and went up on to the curb and hit the pedestrians.

So they would have hit the pedestrians if you will, coming from behind in many cases and they would have been driving, sort of, up on that major part of the artery on Young Street.

WEBSTER: Catherine, you know, we've seen this played out in London, in Barcelona, in Berlin to your point, a main thoroughfare being targeted. But seeing from the helicopter shots, it appears to be a white Ryder van or rental van, which really plays into the M.O. of these terrorists.

HERRIDGE: Well, I mean, there are a lot of circumstantial pieces here to the puzzle that point towards that, but I want to just be a cautious and responsible because we don't know --

WEBSTER: Right.

HERRIDGE: -- who the suspect is or what their motivation is. But certainly, the person who drove that van, and it appears to be a rental van, did so in a part of the city at a time of day near a subway intersection where they would have a maximum sort of impact if you will in terms of casualties. And I think that that was certainly have the attention of police and investigators in Toronto.

WEBSTER: Absolutely. Catherine Herridge, thank you very much for your insight into this.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

WEBSTER: We appreciate it.

HERRIDGE: Sure.

WEBSTER: And, of course, we will continue to follow with more details as they become available in that incident in Toronto.

Devin Nunes says there was no official Intel to justify the Russian investigation. So how does a dossier funded by the opposition spur an FBI probe? We'll examine that, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), CHAIRMAN, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: So we've long wanted to know what intelligence that you have that actually led to this investigation? So what we found now, after the investigators have reviewed it is that, in fact, there was no intelligence.

We now know that there was no official intelligence that was used to start this investigation. We know that Sidney Blumenthal and others were pushing information into the State Department. So we're trying to piece all of that together. And that's why we continue to look at the State Department.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: Oh, what a tangled web we weave. The man leading the House Russian probe Intelligence Committee Chairman, Devin Nunes, right there telling our Maria Bartiromo this weekend there was no intelligence used to begin a probe into any collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia. If you're confused before, just to add to it now.

Joining me now, former Prosecutor David Bruno. All right. David, so to Mr. Nunes' point, they applied for a FISA warrant based solely not as he says on intel, no official intelligence. But based on the dossier, the information provided within that was funded by the Democratic National Committee. Correct?

DAVID BRUNO, FMR. PROSECUTOR AND CRIMINAL DEFENSE ATTORNEY: Well, correct. And these are two different issues. What Devin Nunes just talked about --

WEBSTER: Yes.

BRUNO: -- is how the investigation was started. We know that it was started in July of 2016. And it was started as a result of a conversation that George Papadopoulos had with an Australian diplomat.

WEBSTER: In the bar?

BRUNO: Right, right. So, in the Schiff Minority memorandum on FISA, they point to that. They say it wasn't Steele that initiated investigation. It was the Papadopoulos information. What we found out is that the information about the Papadopoulos statements didn't come through normal channels. We would expect that it would come through these five eyes agreement, which is a partnership with Australia.

WEBSTER: Yes.

BRUNO: And there are no reports, there's nothing to document that information coming our way. So the next question is, if it didn't come through the proper channels --

WEBSTER: Where did it come from?

BRUNO: -- where did it come from? That's what they're looking at. That's what important when it comes --

WEBSTER: That you have a copy here, but it's redacted. So we don't know yet.

BRUNO: Sure. I have it and everyone is welcome to look at the Schiff FISA memorandum. It is a part of it where it says that wait a second, this is not open based on Steele. It's opened by the Papadopoulos information that came from the Australians.

WEBSTER: Well, listen, let's talk about Steele because a lot was being made of this. He was actually terminated by the FBI even though the information that he accumulated for them was used?

BRUNO: Sure. He was terminated for leaking stuff to the press, right?

WEBSTER: Correct.

BRUNO: And there's arguments to be made that the information that he provided to the press was also used in the FISA applications, which is called circular reporting. So the argument was made that, well, there's press information that corroborates Steele, but Steele was the actual source. A lot to be made, let's not forget, there are multiple referrals to the DOJ and the FBI as Steele was a target of criminal investigation. It could come to that.

WEBSTER: So all we've heard is Russia, Russia, Russia, Russia, nothing yet of any substance at all. How long does this go on, and is it to the point where they're going to have to find something to justify everything that's come up to this point?

BRUNO: Nobody knows how long. I mean --

WEBSTER: But you said --

BRUNO: -- how -- now, it could go on into finances. It could go on into past history. We've seen that in the Gates-Manafort indictment, right?

WEBSTER: Right, yes.

BRUNO: That had nothing to do with Russian collusion, it was money laundering, it was tax related information. So how far can he go on? He could go on for a while? Hopefully for the country's sake, for our market sake, for all of our sake --

WEBSTER: This is bond.

BRUNO: -- it will end quickly.

WEBSTER: All right, we're already out of time but, David Bruno, thank you so much.

BRUNO: Good to see you, Ashley.

WEBSTER: It can make your eyes glaze over. That's for sure. But we're staying up with it. David, thank you very much.

OK, this may be a possible sign of things to come. Five ships carrying more than $200 million worth of U.S. sorghum changed course in the ocean after China announced massive tariffs.

Jeff Flock, following the story from this side of the pacific where it will have an impact, right, Jeff?

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: You said it, yes, yes, sir. You know, it's planting time. It's spring planting season out here, and this field was -- when I'm walking through here and now maybe you can tell because there's corn litter. This was corn. But if you're thinking about planting sorghum, sorghum that feed grain, farmers maybe having second thoughts about that.

I want to show you a picture of one of the ships you're talking about, Ashley. And that was a ship called the N Bonanza. It was one of 20 ships loaded with sorghum being sent to China. We export about 80 percent of our sorghum grown in this country to China about a billion dollars worth last year, $2 billion worth just a couple years ago.

And those ships as you point out, many of them turned around because the tariff was 179 percent that to retaliate against President Trump's tariffs. As you can imagine, if you're charging almost double a tax on what you already paid for the sorghum, pretty much, that's not really a winning deal.

So, what can I tell you? Sorghum farmers in the Midwest places like Kansas, which is the number one sorghum state, pretty upset about that. I want to give you a quote from, I think, it's from -- well, I was going to give you a quote from Pat Toomey who said, this is collateral damage. But actually, this is one from the Chinese.

You know they say, the reason they put these tariffs on is because the U.S. was dumping cheap sorghum into their market. The reality is, we actually were selling to China because they were paying a premium for our sorghum, not cheap sorghum. In fact, one of the Chinese companies said, even though this price is very high, we still want to import. We think more and more sorghum will come into China and we will buy and import sorghum also. That was all before all of this trade business started.

So, I know we say it's not a trade war. But I'll tell you, it's a battle certainly. And it's one that's already claiming some casualties.

WEBSTER: Yes. Jeff, very quickly, what happens to all that sorghum out in the ocean? I mean, do you bring it back or do you try and find another buyer somewhere in the region?

FLOCK: We have found, at least in one case that N Bonanza, the ship that I showed you the picture of --

WEBSTER: Yes.

FLOCK: -- that actually is headed to Singapore. So they are able to redirect some of it. But right now, the sorghum market on the gulf coast, which is where a lot of it comes from, completely bottomed out. I mean, there's nobody that's buying in sorghum. So if you're sitting on sorghum, you're sitting on a pile of nothing right at the moment.

WEBSTER: Not good. All right, Jeff Flock, thank you so much. Jeff out in the field in Illinois.

FLOCK: Thanks, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Bernie Sanders, well, he molded to the mainstream. Now more Democratic candidates are calling themselves socialists. But is this really where the Democratic Party wants to go? We'll debate that, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Well, guess what? Socialism is apparently becoming mainstream in the wake of the Bernie Sanders campaign and in response to the resistance against Donald Trump. Growing number of candidates are, well, running as socialists.

The National Party, the Democratic Socialists of America has growing from about 5000 members back in 2016 to 35,000 nationwide. All right, interesting development.

Let's bring in the political panel now. Democratic Strategist John Summers and Republican Strategist Boyd Matheson.

John, let me begin with you. You know, I lived through the socialist era of Britain in the 1970s. It was a disaster. And I'm very glad I will never have to go through that again, at least, I thought so. Now we're hearing this "s" word come up again.

Why is socialism seen as answer especially among millennials?

JON SUMMERS, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, I think what we're saying is people who are tired of the same old, same law, I think they're seeing they haven't been represented by Washington very well at all. I mean, we see this on both sides of the political spectrum. People are dissatisfied. This is one of the reasons why Donald Trump was elected.

I think the midterms will show that there are still a lot of possibilities. He told them what they wanted to hear.

But now, we actually have candidates who feeling bold to stand up for the things they believe in like, healthcare for all, raising the minimum wage, things that strengthen the middle class, because a stronger middle class is a stronger America.

WEBSTER: Boyd, I've always seen socialism as wanting something for nothing. You know, I look at East Germany, West Germany. I look at Cuba, South Miami. I look at North Korea, South Korea.

I know where the people are trying to get out. And I know where they're trying to go, and it's generally from socialist countries to capitalist countries. And I think that says it all. What say you?

BOYD MATHESON, OPINION EDITOR, DESERET NEWS: Yes. Well, obviously the biggest problem with socialism that eventually you do run out of other people's money and then everything breaks down and you have to flee. But I do think the point is right in terms of neither party have given people a reason to be part of the party, especially millennials. They're not getting it.

And I think many of the polls show that millennials actually associate with the term socialism but most of them don't know what it really means. And when they start having jobs, and start seeing how much of their paycheck automatically vanishes to the federal government, then they start having a problem.

And so I think what you're going to see is, many of these Democrats who are using the socialist label, they're going to get labeled as beyond Bernie's. People don't know what socialism is, but they know what is beyond Bernie Sanders. So they'll be the beyond Bernie folks. And it's fine.

Socialism is fine for a Democratic primary in the spring but it does not fly in a real election in the fall. And I think that's going to be the challenge Democrats will face, much like the Republicans have on the right with some of those more extreme candidates.

WEBSTER: What do you say, John? I mean, there are those that say the Democrat Party is out of touch with the working people. And that's what Donald Trump tapped into. And if they go too far left, do you alienate more than you attract?

SUMMERS: Well, I think Boyd and I agree on a lot of the same things, believe it or not.

WEBSTER: What?

SUMMERS: I think it would be difficult to run as a socialist, you know, but I think he is right, I think that a lot of peoples especially millennials aren't familiar with exactly what that term means. I think what they're actually looking for is something different. They're looking for economic equity. They're looking for people who are willing to stand up for what they believe in. Not only just talk the talk, but actually walk the walk, and look out for things like increasing the minimum wage and income equality and that sort of thing.

WEBSTER: But, Boyd, from a Republican point of view, you've got to like this? Don't you think that the further left, the Democrats want to go, the better it may be for more mainstream America in the Republican Party, perhaps?

MATHESON: You know, I think the country is going to continue to remain center left, center right. It's going to be in that wheelhouse. I do think one of the things that the Democrats have tapped into is this misconception of capitalism and crony capitalism. And if the Republicans don't take on the crony part of that, they'll continue to struggle and have that problem as well.

I think President Trump went in talking about, you know, getting rid of the swamp and the cronyism component of that, which does give unfair advantage to the wealthy and well-connected. There is a reason why six out of the 10 wealthiest counties in America are suburbs of Washington D.C.

So it is a narrative that does swing both ways. I don't think Republicans should be comfortable on anything at this point and neither should the Democrats because we could see a real shift.

WESBTER: Right.

MATHESON: You could see the millennials come out in force for smaller parties, some of these broken smaller fragmented parties and that would really change the game. Because they will be probably over 50 percent of the votes come November.

WEBSTER: All right. Well --

MATHESON: I probably agree and I think -- oh sorry.

WEBSTER: -- we're out of time, guys. You're just to way too agreeable. That's the problem with this. I never thought I would see it, but I did.

John and Boyd, we're out of time. Thanks so much. We'll find an issue you can go at it next time, I promise.

And we'll be right back with more Intel.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Well, as we reported, the suspect in Sunday's Waffle House shooting in Nashville, Tennessee has been arrested. Police say 29-year-old Travis Reinking was taken into custody in a wooded area not far from for his apartment. Police and federal agents making the arrest after a massive manhunt. Reinking was reportedly nearly naked when he opened fire at the Waffle House killing four people.

A news conference by the way has been has been scheduled for the next hour.

The market as we're talking it now is down 109 point. I also want to bring you up to speed on the Canadian story. In Toronto, the driver of the van plowing into at least eight pedestrians is also in custody.

Toronto police not revealing any calls or motive behind the crash but police say the van apparently jump the curb and then hit pass it or hit the people walking down the street in the middle of Toronto. Busy news day.

Liz Claman, I'll throw it to you.

END

urn:contentItem:5S5X-J7H1-JBHT-D447-00000-00French President Arrives in the U.S. Ahead of Trump's First State Dinner; North Korea to Suspend Nuke Tests; Earnings in Focus this Week; Pompeo Confirmation Battle; Nunes: No Intel Found; Five Ships Carrying U.S. Sorghum Changes Course in Ocean after China Announced Massive Tariffs; Socialism Goes Mainstream2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrench President Arrives in the U.S. Ahead of Trump's First State Dinner; North Korea to Suspend Nuke Tests; Earnings in Focus this Week; Pompeo Confirmation Battle; Nunes: No Intel Found; Five Ships Carrying U.S. Sorghum Changes Course in Ocean after China Announced Massive Tariffs; Socialism Goes MainstreamLanhamFULL TEXT

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Here is Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan. He will take you to the next hour.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Every day is a busy day, Charles. Thank you very much.

PAYNE: All right.

WEBSTER: Breaking right now, French President Emmanuel Macron just landing at Joint Base Andrews as he begins a three-day state visit hosted by President Trump. We're also keeping an eye on your money, of course, as U.S. Treasury yields creep towards three percent, which is sparking new fears of a bear market on Wall Street. We shall see.

Good afternoon, everybody, and welcome. I'm Ashley Webster in for Trish Regan and on now to THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT.

President Trump and Macron will look to strengthen their, well, bromance if you like as both men have a lot riding on this week's visit where trade and the Iran nuclear deal are set to dominate the agenda. I'll be discussing this with former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee straight ahead.

Plus, of course, North Korea says it will suspend all nuclear tests ahead of its historic summit with South Korea. President Trump tweeting this, "We are a long way from conclusion on North Korea, maybe things will work out, and maybe they won't. Only time will tell." We have more on that coming up.

Lots to talk about. But, first, French President Emmanuel Macron as we say just landing on American soil, now is making his way to Washington to meet with President Trump. Do we have Fox -- do we have -- he's good. We have Fox News's Doug McKelway. He's at the White House with more on the big state visit.

Doug.

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Ashley. President Macron touched down at Joint Base Andrews just within the past hour. And his motorcade as we speak is just pulled up to Blair House about a block away he and the First Lady of France will stay there for the next couple of hours before they come here to the White House, board a helicopter with the first couple of the United States for a trip across the Potomac River where they will dine at the George Washington's Mount Vernon tonight before the first state dinner of the Trump administration which takes place here at the White House tomorrow.

These two get along famously as best as we can tell that they came evidently as early as last summer when President Trump went to Paris to enjoy Bastille Day, and came away from that meeting, having a very close personal relationship with Mr. Macron. He also came away from that meeting suggesting we have a military parade here in the United States. That is not to say that they're not considerable differences between the two gentlemen.

May 12th, for example, is a deadline for Mr. Trump to decide whether to lift sanctions on Iran. The press secretary was asked about that just in the briefing a few moments ago, which is now underway. Here is what she had to say, Sarah Huckabee Sanders.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: But what you do have are two leaders who have a great deal of respect for one another, who have a great friendship. Certainly, both have a great deal of interests in doing what is best for their country, but being able to have very open and candid conversations because of the relationship not only that the leaders have built, but that has existed between the two countries long before either of these individuals arrived on the scene. And we're going to continue that relationship. But I think we can expect this to be a very productive and very positive state visit for both countries.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: She added that she does not want to get ahead of any discussions that two might have before they actually occur. Macron, however, does believes that it would be a bad decision to get out of the Iran nuclear deal. Here's what he had to say this weekend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, PRESIDENT OF FRANCE: Is this agreement perfect and this JCPOA perfect thing for our relationship with Iran? No. But for nuclear, what do you have as a better option? I don't see it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: And May 1st is another important deadline, a time for Mr. Trump to decide whether he wants to impose tariffs on the European Union for its importation of steel and aluminum. Again, Mr. Macron thinks that would be a bad idea for Mr. Trump to do.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MACRON: You cannot make a trade your allies. I'm very -- I'm an easy guy. I'm very simple. I'm straight forward.

It's too complicated if you make war against everybody. You make trade war against China, trade war against Europe, war in Syria, war against Iran. Come on. It doesn't work. You need allies. We are the ally.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: The First Lady coming out of the shadows a little bit for this state dinner tonight. She is apparently behind all of the minute planning of this first state dinner coming tomorrow night. The first state dinner of the Trump administration.

Ashley, back to you.

WEBSTER: It's going to be quite an affair. Doug McKelway at the White House. Doug, thank you very much.

MCKELWAY: My pleasure.

WEBSTER: Joining me now to talk about that and other issues, FormerArkansas Governor Mike Huckabee. Great to see you, Governor.

You know what politics can makes for strange bedfellows, and here we have maybe Mr. Trump's lone ally in Europe right now because he's had a public spat with Theresa May and the U.K. And here we have Emmanuel Macron, who by all accounts is a political outsider who also managed to outwit the political establishment in France. So maybe it's not so strange that these two individuals kind of get along?

MIKE HUCKABEE (R), FORMER ARKANSAS GOVERNOR: Well, I think a lot of it has to do with what you just mentioned. They're both outsiders, but they're also very plain-spoken people. And they're honest with each other. The President likes that. He really does.

For all those who think that he wants to be surrounded by yes men, they don't know him very well. He doesn't like to be ridiculed in public but he does not mind having people in the meetings with him speak their mind. Clearly, President Macron is able, willing to do that. They have very frank and open discussions.

And the good thing is, look at this. I think it's the best relationship we've seen with France in many years.

WEBSTER: Yes.

HUCKABEE: And we didn't even have to bring James Taylor in to sing for it.

WEBSTER: I love the sarcasm. It's an effective form of wit despite what Stuart Varney says. OK. So, look, you know they're going to be talking, Governor, about, you know, militarily ironically.

France has been right with the U.S., both against ISIS and in Syria. But then we have the nuke deal with Iran. We have trade. We have climate change.

Can they get any common ground? Because I don't think the President is going to say, "He's kind of hinted yes, OK, maybe we can get back into the Paris climate accord." I don't see that happening. And with regard to the Iran nuke deal, we heard Macron speaking this weekend. It doesn't feel like they're going to get any common ground there.

HUCKABEE: They maybe not, Ashley. But I think that there is a likelihood that there will be some compromise on both parties to bring something to the table that works. But the President has been very clear. He's President of the United States.

He doesn't capitulate to any other country. He does what's best for America. And he expects every other world leader to do the exact same thing for their country.

But if he can be convinced whether it's by Macron or one of the others that this is really in the best interests of the United States I think he is open to it. But I'll be very clear to say, if it's not in the best interests of the United States he's not interested at all. This President is not in simply trying to be popular with world leaders. He wants to be effective in making sure that he takes care of America.

WEBSTER: Absolutely true. OK, we're gong to completely change gears. Now I want to ask you about this one. Canadian country singer Shania Twain issuing an apology after getting a lot of backlash for saying she would have voted for Donald Trump in the 2016 election.

I mean, how could she say such a thing? What are your thoughts?

HUCKABEE: It's so sad that the left refuses to allow anyone to speak his or her mind without being just pilloried and excoriated unless they agree with the left of center viewpoint that they hold. This is the most intolerant bunch of people I've ever seen in my life, Ashley, and this is a great example.

You know, it's sad that Shania Twain felt like she had to apologize, but the backlash that she got for simply expressing an opinion, why can't she do that? She ought to be able to. Tragic day.

WEBSTER: Yes, exactly. We've seen it, you know, certainly coming out of Hollywood in the movie business. No different, I guess, in the music business as well.

HUCKABEE: Too bad and it's unfortunate. We need to be able to have the kind of honest discussions that we're seeing between the French and American President where we don't always agree but we do it respectfully.

WEBSTER: Very well-said. Governor Huckabee, thank you so much for joining us today. I really appreciate it.

HUCKABEE: Thanks.

And when they start having jobs, and start seeing how much of their paycheck automatically vanishes to the federal government, then they start having a problem.

And so I think what you're going to see is, many of these Democrats who are using the socialist label, they're going to get labeled as beyond Bernie's. People don't know what socialism is, but they know what is beyond Bernie Sanders. So they'll be the beyond Bernie folks. And it's fine.

Socialism is fine for a Democratic primary in the spring but it does not fly in a real election in the fall. And I think that's going to be the challenge Democrats will face, much like the Republicans have on the right with some of those more extreme candidates.

WEBSTER: What do you say, John? I mean, there are those that say the Democrat Party is out of touch with the working people. And that's what Donald Trump tapped into. And if they go too far left, do you alienate more than you attract?

SUMMERS: Well, I think Boyd and I agree on a lot of the same things, believe it or not.

WEBSTER: What?

SUMMERS: I think it would be difficult to run as a socialist, you know, but I think he is right, I think that a lot of peoples especially millennials aren't familiar with exactly what that term means. I think what they're actually looking for is something different. They're looking for economic equity. They're looking for people who are willing to stand up for what they believe in. Not only just talk the talk, but actually walk the walk, and look out for things like increasing the minimum wage and income equality and that sort of thing.

WEBSTER: But, Boyd, from a Republican point of view, you've got to like this? Don't you think that the further left, the Democrats want to go, the better it may be for more mainstream America in the Republican Party, perhaps?

MATHESON: You know, I think the country is going to continue to remain center left, center right. It's going to be in that wheelhouse. I do think one of the things that the Democrats have tapped into is this misconception of capitalism and crony capitalism. And if the Republicans don't take on the crony part of that, they'll continue to struggle and have that problem as well.

I think President Trump went in talking about, you know, getting rid of the swamp and the cronyism component of that, which does give unfair advantage to the wealthy and well-connected. There is a reason why six out of the 10 wealthiest counties in America are suburbs of Washington D.C.

So it is a narrative that does swing both ways. I don't think Republicans should be comfortable on anything at this point and neither should the Democrats because we could see a real shift.

WESBTER: Right.

MATHESON: You could see the millennials come out in force for smaller parties, some of these broken smaller fragmented parties and that would really change the game. Because they will be probably over 50 percent of the votes come November.

WEBSTER: All right. Well --

MATHESON: I probably agree and I think -- oh sorry.

WEBSTER: -- we're out of time, guys. You're just to way too agreeable. That's the problem with this. I never thought I would see it, but I did.

John and Boyd, we're out of time. Thanks so much. We'll find an issue you can go at it next time, I promise.

And we'll be right back with more Intel.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WEBSTER: Well, as we reported, the suspect in Sunday's Waffle House shooting in Nashville, Tennessee has been arrested. Police say 29-year-old Travis Reinking was taken into custody in a wooded area not far from for his apartment. Police and federal agents making the arrest after a massive manhunt. Reinking was reportedly nearly naked when he opened fire at the Waffle House killing four people.

A news conference by the way has been has been scheduled for the next hour.

The market as we're talking it now is down 109 point. I also want to bring you up to speed on the Canadian story. In Toronto, the driver of the van plowing into at least eight pedestrians is also in custody.

Toronto police not revealing any calls or motive behind the crash but police say the van apparently jump the curb and then hit pass it or hit the people walking down the street in the middle of Toronto. Busy news day.

Liz Claman, I'll throw it to you.

END
