Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T75-2K51-JCMN-Y071-00000-00From Democracy to Technocracy2018-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom Democracy to TechnocracyShelly Palmer

Sep 09, 2018( Shelly Palmer Digital Living: http://www.shellypalmer.com/category/blog/ Delivered by Newstex) During the recent congressional hearings, Sen. Mark Warner (D-VA), the Senate intelligence committee's vice chairman, said, 'The era of the wild west in social media is coming to an end.' Congress, he said, will have to take action. 'Where we go from here is an open question.'

More hearings are clearly in the offing, and some kind of regulation is likely to follow. That's the probable future, but what would happen if the government lost its ability to control the tech industry? What if tech fought back? What if our democracy transformed into a technocracy?Facebook, Twitter, and Google (FTG)I'll use FTG as a proxy for content you can find on the public Internet. During 2018 at three different congressional hearings, FTG was variously accused of 'allowing' bad actors to use, and abuse, their platforms. The proper use of FTG should not have been called into question, because FTG's business model is putting the right message in front of the right person at the right time. The abuse by bad actors who created fake accounts and deployed bots and trolls is a legitimate area of concern, and everyone knows it must be dealt with. Then there is the concept of Fake News and the tactical reality of censorship. Like pornography, you might know Fake News when you see it, but well-crafted propaganda rarely identifies itself. Whether human, machine, or a hybrid of both, someone or something has to determine what is acceptable and what is not. Whom would you anoint with that level of power?Damned If You Do, Damned If You Don'tAt least some government legislators believe that FTG has the power to accurately predict voter behavior and, more importantly, has the power to alter the course of elections. This is not an unreasonable thought. FTG is capable of high-level predictive modeling and has the ability to test messaging hypotheses quickly and efficiently. Which raises the question, 'Could Mark Zuckerberg or Jack Dorsey or Larry Page have swung the outcome of the 2016 presidential election to the candidate of his choice?' I believe that Facebook or Google could have easily put its candidate of choice in the White House. But I also believe that the company's CEO would currently be in jail if either had done so. But FTG took a different path: it followed the existing laws, which state that because Facebook, Twitter, and Google are 'neutral platforms,' FTG is not required to monitor illegal activity. In other words, it was business as usual, and FTG's reward was congressional hearings. Follow the law and get a subpoena or fix the elections and go to jail - decisions, decisions. Oddly, when asked by Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-AK) whether Facebook was a tech company or a publisher, Zuckerberg answered, 'When people ask us if we're a media company — or a publisher — my understanding of what the heart of what they're really getting at is, 'Do we feel responsibility for the content on our platform?' The answer to that, I think, is clearly yes.' But what does he mean by 'we?' Does he mean a set of policies crafted by a diverse group of democratically elected representatives? Or does he mean the royal we, in other words, him?The TransformationJust for fun, let's imagine a world where the US government decides it is going to take big tech out to the woodshed. Congress has a bunch of hearings. Committees and subcommittees are formed and regulations are crafted. In this hypothetical world, FTG is really unhappy with the government getting in its face and the CEOs decide it's time to fight back. Playing this out, FTG sets out to replace the regulators with elected officials who are sympathetic (or subservient) to FTG's cause. It works because FTG is that powerful. Then the CEOs in traditional 1930s Gangland-style start divvying up the territory. They invite the other bosses (Microsoft, Amazon, Apple, etc.). And poof! In three election cycles, America is transformed from a democracy into a technocracy - and no one (except those on the inside) would even know.The EvolutionIt's possible that a technocratic republic would provide a better quality of life than the current constitutional republic. Turning data into action is what big tech does, and for our country to sustain its position as a world leader, it needs technological mastery as a core competence. A technocracy would be run far more efficiently than our current system, and it would be impossible for politicians to do anything other than what they were told to do for the good of the technocracy. However, this vision of a benevolent dictatorial technocracy is nave in the extreme. Everything might be great for a while, but then the CEOs would start to disagree or get into turf wars or some other conflict, and they would start fighting with each other with weaponized technology. In the end, some working-class hero would raise up an army and reclaim America for Americans - and in the process probably set the clock back to the Stone Age. Fodder for a B-movie script? Nope. It's not good enough.What's NextCongress is looking for a fight. Big Tech is not. The process may end with some mild, uninformed regulations that can be easily dealt with, or it may yield draconian regulations that inhibit innovation and growth, or we might end up with some amped-up privacy laws and some regulations around omni-platform advertising and messaging. Whatever the regulations turn out to be, they will apply to everyone, and every business is capable of adapting to a level playing field. In reality, I am not too worried about government tech regulation. But what if Big Tech decides to fight back? What would that America look like? I'd love to hear your thoughts. I'm @shellypalmer[1] on Twitter. That seems like the perfect place for this discussion. Author's note:This is not a sponsored post. I am the author of this article and it expresses my own opinions. I am not, nor is my company, receiving compensation for it. urn:contentItem:60RG-H9V1-F03R-N49M-00000-00From Facebook to Tesla, here are the lesser-known cofounders of some of the biggest tech companies in the world2020-09-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom Facebook to Tesla, here are the lesser-known cofounders of some of the biggest tech companies in the worldAvery Hartmans

Sep 01, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Most of the world's most famous tech entrepreneurs had help building their companies.And while Mark Zuckerberg's and Steve Job's cofounders didn't all become household names, they're still credited with bringing Facebook and Apple to life.Tesla, for instance, had four cofounders, and none of them was Elon Musk.And Jack Dorsey is one of four people who helped create Twitter.Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[1]. When a tech company reaches a certain level of success, the names of the founders often become synonymous with the brand they create — at least, that's the case with founders who are the "face" of the company.Still, we tend to forget that Steve Jobs, Travis Kalanick, and Bill Gates didn't create Apple, Uber, and Microsoft alone.On the contrary, these companies might not exist in the same capacity if it weren't for the cofounders who fly under the radar either because they chose to steer clear of the spotlight or because the pressures brought on by the early years of a quickly growing company pushed them away. Many of these same people have moved on to create other multimillion-dollar ideas, while others left for a life of philanthropy, or pursued another passion.Here are the lesser-known cofounders who helped create some of the world's biggest tech companies.Prachi Bhardwaj contributed to an earlier version of this article.

Steve Wozniak designed and built the first Apple computer, the Apple 1. Steve Wozniak (a.k.a. "Woz") doesn't reallyneed an introduction, but for those who aren't well-versed in the history of Apple, Wozniak formed Apple along with Steve Jobs in 1976.Wozniak was working at Hewlett-Packard at the time, where he tried to share his computer design. When he was denied multiple times[2], Steve Jobs — who was working there for the summer — suggested the pair try to sell a fully assembled version of the design to a third party.As Apple grew, Wozniak felt the emphasis on marketing hindered him as an engineer, and he left for good in 1985[3], but he's still the sole inventor on multiple Apple patents, including the "Microcomputer for use with video display[4]."The same year he left Apple, Wozniak finished earning his degree from UC Berkeley (under the fake name "Rocky Clark"[5]) and founded a company that built the first programmable universal remote control.[6]Wozniak has since cofounded two more companies, multiple non-profits[7], including the Electronic Frontier Foundation, and the Silicon Valley Comic Con[8]. He's on multiple company boards, and remains on the official Apple employee list[9]. He's also an Apple shareholder. Ronald Wayne, the third cofounder of Apple, met Jobs and Wozniak while working at Atari. When Jobs and Wozniak formed "Apple Computer" in 1976 Ronald Wayne drew up the first logo and the partnership agreement[10] that gave him 10% of the company.But Wayne, who was 42 at the time, only lasted for 12 days[11] before deciding he couldn't keep up with the pace the company was going. Wayne sold his shares for $800 — a decision he says he doesn't regret[12].Today, Wayne has written two books, holds dozens of patents, and sells gold, rare coins, and stamps from his home in Nevada. He has since auctioned off his Apple archive[13]. Garrett Camp is credited with inventing Uber. Former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick wasn't the one to come up with the original idea for Uber."Garrett [Camp] is the guy who invented that s---," Kalanick once said[14] at an early Uber event in San Francisco. "I just want to clap and hug him at the same time."Camp described what we know as "ride-sharing" to Kalanick when they attended the 2008 LeWeb conference: He wanted to create a convenient luxury car service that didn't cost a thousand dollars to use. Kalanick was on board, and UberCab started later that year[15].The initial prototype was created by Camp. Kalanick was brought on as a "mega advisor" and wasn't named CEO until 2010[16], when he replaced then CEO Ryan Graves.Camp earned his first fortune when he sold the web-recommendation tool StumbleUpon to eBay in 2007. He's also an investor, creator of startup studio Expa — which helps new founders build their own products — and launched a nonprofit called the Camp Foundation.Camp served on Uber's board[17] until March 2020. He owns about a 4% stake[18] in the company. Twitter had three cofounders: Ev Williams, Noah Glass, and Biz Stone. Jack Dorsey played a huge role in developing Twitter as a product, but he wasn't technically the founder of the company.Twitter spun out from Odeo[19], a podcast company cofounded by Noah Glass and Evan "Ev" Williams (an ex-Googler who cofounded Blogger before it was sold to Google).Williams pushed the team to come up with a new idea when iTunes announced the podcasting platform for iPods in 2005, and an idea from Jack Dorsey, an Odeo web designer, caught Glass' attention. Glass worked with Dorsey and a contract developer named Florian Webber to pitch Twitter, and came up with the name (then "Twttr"[20]). The other two built the prototype, but the service eventually ran on Glass' laptop, an IBM Thinkpad.Biz Stone, another ex-Googler brought on by Williams, helped the Twitter team out from time to time, and wrote some of the legal documentation[21].The following year, Williams bought all of Odeo — including Twitter — from shareholders, changed it to Obvious Corp. (which he says he cofounded with Stone), and allegedly fired Glass. The reason isn't entirely clear, though the most common belief is that Williams and Glass had clashing personalities. (The entire history of Twitter, and the relationship between Glass and Williams, is spelled out in a Business Insider story from 2011[22].)Today, Stone is an angel investor and cofounder of multiple companies. He has invested in both Dorsey's and Williams' other ventures.Williams was briefly Twitter's CEO and still has a stake in the company, but is now the founder and CEO of publishing platform Medium.Not much is publicly known about Glass other than his Twitter profile,[23] which reads, simply, "I started this." Jim McKelvey cofounded Square along with Jack Dorsey. When Square was founded in 2009, the name "Jack Dorsey" overshadowed McKelvey's, but both parties were responsible for the popular mobile-payments app.Dorsey had once written software for McKelvey, and after he was ousted as Twitter's CEO, the two happened to reconnect."We started Square because Jim McKelvey, our cofounder and my second boss (after my mother!), couldn't accept a credit card for his art," Dorsey said about McKelvey in the founders' letter from Square's S-1 filing[24] before the company went public.McKelvey shared his problem with Dorsey, and the two came up with the idea for Square. McKelvey designed the hardware and built the magnetic reader, while Dorsey wrote the software[25].Today, McKelvey sits on the board of directors at Square. Since starting Square, he has founded two other companies: LaunchCode[26] and Invisibly[27], according to his LinkedIn profile[28]. He wrote a book, which came out in March, called "The Innovation Stack." Automaker Tesla had four cofounders: Martin Eberhard, Marc Tarpenning, Ian Wright, and JB Straubel. There are two versions of how Tesla got its start: One is that Tesla was actually[29] the 2003 brainchild of Martin Eberhard and Marc Tarpenning. The two engineers raised as much as they could without help, but ultimately needed to land a big investor to lead the Series A funding round.Ian Wright — who was third to join the team followed by JB Straubel — and Eberhard successfully pitched Tesla to Elon Musk in 2004.In Musk's version of events, both he and the Tesla Motors crew were equally interested in commercializing a tiny electric roadster called the tZero[30]. The company behind the car, AC Propulsion, declined to bring it to market, but did introduce Musk and Tesla Motors. The group decided to team up, which led to the formation of Tesla as we know it today.Either way, Musk led two funding rounds and co-led a third before Tesla's first production vehicle, the Roadster, was finally unveiled in 2006[31]. Both Eberhard and Tarpenning left after Eberhard was demoted from his position as CEO in 2007, and one CEO later, Musk took on the leading role.Eberhard then sued Musk and Tesla[32], claiming libel, slander, and breach of contract. Eberhard alleged that Tesla had wrongfully tried to "rewrite history" by taking away his position as the founder. He eventually withdrew the case and part of the resolution[33] was that there would be five official founders of Tesla.Today, Eberhard and Tarpenning have worked together on a number of other electric vehicle projects, including Volkswagen and SF Motors[34]. Wright left a year after joining Tesla, and founded Wrightspeed[35], which develops electric parts for trucks. JB Straubel was still the CTO of Tesla until July 2019.[36] Snap CTO Bobby Murphy founded the company with Evan Spiegel. Bobby Murphy and Evan Spiegel met when they were Kappa Sigma fraternity brothers at Stanford University.Murphy was studying mathematical and computational science and Spiegel was studying product design — they put their heads together to develop the prototype of an app that would make pictures disappear after they were shared.Murphy worked 18-hour days coding the prototype, and took a day job with the iPad-based register company Revel Systems[37] before Snapchat took off. He remains the CTO of Snap and has written most of the code for today's Snapchat application.Both Snap cofounders have a nearly equal net worth (between $4.6 billion and $4.8 billion as of September 2020, according to Forbes[38]), but Murphy prefers to keep a much lower profile[39]than his counterpart. Snap initially had a third cofounder, Reggie Brown. The Spiegel-Murphy duo was initially a trio, and the forgotten third member — Reggie Brown — was reportedly the idea man. In 2013, he took the matter to court.Brown, also a Kappa Sigma brother, approached Spiegel with a concept for an app that sends pictures that disappear shortly after they're shared.Spiegel recruited Murphy because neither he nor Brown had the coding chops. The three of them reportedly had a non-written agreement[40] to share ownership and profit: Spiegel as CEO, Murphy as CTO, and Brown as CMO.Brown came up with "Picaboo," the first name for the app, as well as the logo: a now widely recognizable ghost, who he named "Ghostface Chillah." But monthsafter Snapchat launched in the iTunes Store — a glimpse at the celebration is pictured above — Spiegel and Brown reportedly felt that Brown was bringing little else to the table as CMO, and allegedly changed the passwords on the startup's servers and accounts.In 2013, Brown sued[41] his two former friends for breach of contract, and they settled a year later. Snapchat released a statement[42] saying that Brown did come up with the idea, and he was paid $157.5 million, according to Snap's SEC filings for 2014 and 2016. Brown has kept a low profile since.The little that we know about Brown's whereabouts are that he hadn't had a paying job at the time of the lawsuit, and that he graduated with a master's degree in management studies from Duke University in May 2014. Microsoft was founded by two people: Bill Gates and the late Paul Allen. Bill Gates and Paul Allen became friends in high school and founded Microsoft in 1975. Allen came up with the name (originally Micro-Soft, according to a 1995 interview[43] in Fortune), and then sealed the deal for a technology that attracted IBM, resulting in Micro-Soft's take-off.Allen left Microsoft in 1982 when he was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma,[44] a cancer that affects the immune system. He had another bout of cancer in 2009, and in 2018, announced that his cancer had returned for the third time[45]. Allen died soon after[46] at age 65.Allen was a philanthropist, donating more than $2 billion[47] during his lifetime. He was also involved in numerous other ventures, including his ownership of the Portland Trail Blazers and Seattle Seahawks and the Allen Institute for Brain Science. Marc Randolph cofounded Netflix along with Reed Hastings. Marc Randolph and Reed Hastings met when Hastings' company Pure Atria, where he was the founder and CEO, acquired the software company where Randolph worked[48]. Hastings appointed Randolph as vice president of corporate marketing, but soon after, Pure Atria was acquired by Rational Software.During the four months while the Rational-Pure Atria acquisition was being finalized, Hastings and Randolph commuted together to and from Pure Atria's offices in Silicon Valley, actively brainstorming ways to leverage trends for a new business idea, according to Randolph's telling of the story[49]. "And back then, Amazon is crushing it with books. What else can we crush it with?"After the two mailed a CD to Hastings' home and it was delivered unharmed,Hastings invested money into the business idea and went to Stanford for a year to earn his master's degree, while Randolph took the reins.Randolph was the first CEO of Netflix. He named the company, and designed both the brand and the interface. Hastings was initially going to be an investor and a board member, but when he started coming to the office more often, executives agreed it was time for a change. Randolph ceded the position to him in 1999[50] to turn to product development, because he missed the start-up phase of the company."As I look back on what some of the smartest things I ever did at Netflix, I think having [Hastings] come back and be a very, very major part of the company, eventually becoming CEO in my place, was probably the smartest thing I ever did there," Randolph said in an interview[51] with Silicon Valley Business Journal.Randolph stayed on the board until 2003[52], a year after the company went public. Since then, he's been a board member and founder of a number of companies, including data analytics company Looker, and a keynote speaker[53]about entrepreneurship and innovation based on his time with Netflix. PayPal was cofounded by multiple people besides Peter Thiel: Max Levchin, Luke Nosek, and Ken Howery. The former employees of PayPal came to be known as the "PayPal mafia," because a number of them went on to found other huge technology companies. But it all started with Peter Thiel.Thiel met Max Levchin when Thiel was giving a lecture at Stanford, according to Conner Forrest's reporting in TechRepublic[54], and the two began working together on a digital wallet. Thiel attended Stanford, and Levchin attended the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, which is where almost all of their recruits came from.Luke Nosek[55] had attended UIUC with Levchin, where the two had worked together on cofounding a media company, and Ken Howery[56] was recruited by Thiel after graduating from Stanford. Thiel, Levchin, and Nosek founded Confinity: a company that made software that could transfer payments between handheld devices in 1998, like PalmPilots and PDAs. Thiel was the CEO, and Levchin was the CTO. Nosek was the VP of marketing, strategy, and business development, and Ken Howery was CFO. The product was called PayPal.In 2000, X.com's founder Elon Musk made the decision to acquire Confinity[57]. He was almost immediately replaced by Peter Thiel as CEO, who changed the name to PayPal, Inc.After PayPal was acquired by eBay in 2002, most of the original PayPal mafia moved on.Howery was eBay's director of corporate development, but eventually rejoined Thiel in 2004 to be the VP of private equity at one of Thiel's VC practices, Clarium Capital Management. He then went on to cofound Founders Fund, Thiel's famous VC firm in San Francisco, with Thiel and Nosek. These days, Howery is the US ambassador to Sweden[58].Nosek left Founders Fund in 2017 to start his own investment fund called Gigafund[59], a SpaceX-focused fund.Levchin founded social gaming company Slide in 2004. Google bought it for $182 million in 2010, and Levchin was allowed to run it independently until Google cofounder Larry Page shut it down in 2011. Levchin later founded HVF, which spun out into financial technology company Affirm[60]. He has served as a board member for a number of companies, including Yelp and Evernote. Dustin Moskovitz, Chris Hughes, Andrew McCollum, and Eduardo Saverin all helped create Facebook. The five Facebook founders were classmates at Harvard University. Zuckerberg, who was the mastermind behind thefacebook.com, as the site was called at the time, recruited roommates Moskovitz and Hughes, and two other friends to help him develop it.Zuckerberg had known Eduardo Saverin for about a year when he invited him to join. Saverin was Facebook's first investor and took on the business partner role in the relationship during the early stages of Facebook.Moskovitz, keen on helping Zuckerberg expand the site, learned the PHP language in "a couple of days,"according to Zuckerberg[61], and became the company's first CTO.Hughes served as the spokesman, beta tester, PR specialist, customer service representative, and everything else user-facing, but he didn't write code or handle any of the business.Zuckerberg knew Andrew McCollum from all of their computer-science classes, and he asked him to design Facebook's first logo[62] — a face that was actually a sketch of actor Al Pacino. McCollum also worked on Facebook's file-sharing program called Wirehog, which never took off the way Zuckerberg planned.The summer after the site launched in 2004, Zuckerberg, Hughes, and Moskovitz traveled to Palo Alto, California. Zuckerberg and Moskovitz decided to drop out of Harvard and stay to relocate their operations and start hiring employees. Hughes went back when the semester started, but joined them again when he graduated in 2006.While they were in Palo Alto, Zuckerberg pushed Saverin out, anddiluted his shares[63] to 10% because of what Zuckerberg believed to be Saverin's lack of contribution to the company.Saverin eventually sued Facebook over breach of fiduciary duty. He walked away with 4% of the company, and today he lives in Singapore, having renounced his US citizenship[64] in 2011 — a year before Facebook's IPO, meaning the taxes he had to pay on capital gains were significantly reduced.McCollum left in 2006 is currently the CEO of internet television company Philo[65].Hughes left Facebook in 2007 to volunteer for Barack Obama[66]'s presidential campaign, did non-profit work with Jumo and UNAIDS, and purchased a stake in "The New Republic" magazine, which he later sold.In May 2019, Hughes dropped a bombshell by publishing an op-ed in The New York Times [67]that called regulators to break up Facebook in order to protect users and competition.Moskovitz left in 2008 to cofound team management app Asana[68], which recently filed to go public.[69] Mike Krieger was brought on as a cofounder when Instagram was still in its infancy. Kevin Systrom might have been the more public face of Instagram, but Mike Krieger was there when Instagram was still called "Burbn."Krieger, who had been two years behind Systrom at Stanford, had been working on his own app, called Meebo, when Systrom recruited him. Soon after Krieger joined, the pair decided to pivot Burbn[70], eliminating most of the features to focus solely on photo-sharing.In April 2012, Mark Zuckerberg and Facebook acquired Instagram[71] for $1 billion. The duo stayed at Facebook until 2018[72], when Systrom and Krieger abruptly announced that they were stepping down as CEO and CTO, respectively, and leaving Instagram altogether.Read the original value.Overview: By Fady Abdel-Nour, Global Head of M&A and Investments, PayU Over the course of the last six months, the payments industry has been lauded as one of the most impressive in its agility responding to Covid-19. urn:contentItem:60X7-V9Y1-JCSC-J2XG-00000-00From fundamentals to digital evolution: Deutsche Bank and ACT release comprehensive guide for treasurers2020-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisNEWSFrom fundamentals to digital evolution: Deutsche Bank and ACT release comprehensive guide for treasurers

By Fady Abdel-Nour, Global Head of M&A and Investments, PayU Over the course of the last six months, the payments industry has been lauded as one of the most impressive in its agility responding to Covid-19. Consumers and merchants have flocked online and ... By Fady Abdel-Nour, Global Head of M&A and Investments, PayU Over the course...

By Fady Abdel-Nour, Global Head of M&A and Investments, PayU Over the course of the last six months, the payments industry has been lauded as one of the most impressive in its agility responding to Covid-19. Consumers and merchants have flocked online and ...

By Fady Abdel-Nour, Global Head of M&A and Investments, PayU Over the course of the last six months, the payments industry has been lauded as one of the most impressive in its agility responding to Covid-19. Consumers and merchants have flocked online and safety has been a significant driver of the move to digital as entire countries discourage the use of cash – but what of financial and data security? As digital payments adoption accelerates, there’s no time to waste. The pressure is on for governments and regulators to not only ensure security keeps pace with new consumer demand, but to look ahead and clear the road for future innovation. Acceleration in digital payments At , we operate in 20 markets across the globe. Since the start of the pandemic, every single one of these markets has seen a seismic shift in consumer habits. In Poland, for example, the number of new onboarded e-shops was three times higher between March and May than in previous months. And in Colombia, e-commerce activity was 282% higher than pre-lockdown levels. Some merchants across our markets saw year-on-year revenue growth of a staggering 500-1000% during April and May. New merchants are seeing this potential, moving online to increase their customer base and keep economies ticking. But with great innovation comes corresponding regulations. How can regulators keep up? Innovation vs. regulation: an incompatible duo? New ideas and technologies are undeniably critical to ensure services keep up with consumer behaviour. However, for this to happen safely, there needs to be collaboration between our industry’s innovators and regulators. Progress requires us to challenge and expand existing boundaries, holding our shared goal in mind. Important as this concept is, it is by no means revolutionary. The widely pedalled narrative that innovators and regulators are at loggerheads is, quite frankly, outdated. It is not true that innovation in financial services has to disrupt existing systems and infrastructure. We have already seen countless examples of regulators working with the fintech ecosystem to enable and support innovation. Across the emerging markets that PayU operates in, innovation initiatives are in place to educate entrepreneurs on the regulatory environment in which they operate. In Brazil, the central bank has established a sandbox, the Laboratory of Financial and Technological Innovation, to help fintech startups work more closely with regulators and government and accelerate the development of their ideas. The aim is to create a more efficient financial system, increase financial inclusion and reduce the cost of credit through better regulation. As the country rolls out Open Banking, acknowledging fintech’s potential to drive better socio-economic inclusion is incredibly encouraging. It would be remiss of me not to mention The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) here. To date, it has excelled in driving positive change by ensuring new players and services can operate within regulatory constraints. If they are unable to do so, the MAS reviews its framework and, where appropriate, adjusts it to safely progress innovation rather than stifle it. In 2019, for example, it issued five new digital bank licenses. Later in the year, it launched the Sandbox Express to help create a faster option for testing innovative financial services in the market. The open-minded and collaborative approach of these regulatory models marks the future of financial regulation to me. The world is changing quickly and the parameters that keep us secure have to adapt and morph more than ever before. The job is not simple, but it can boost innovation and build a safe and sustainable financial environment, where pioneers are empowered to set the pace for change. Consumer demand is only one side of the (digital) coin The other trend creating complexity for regulators is the move towards embedded finance and Big Tech’s involvement in this. Fady Abdel-Nour Broadly, embedded finance means that fintech services are expanding beyond the walls of banks and becoming part of other business models rather than a standalone entity. This is a challenge in itself, as regulators will need to be vigilant to ensure that payments, credit and other financial services remain secure and customers are protected. Across Europe, the US, Latin America, Asia and Africa, governments have also been grappling with how to regulate Big Tech. Facebook, for example, has launched ‘Facebook Financial’ to pursue opportunities in digital payments and e-commerce. Similarly, regulators in Brazil and India have been trying to navigate WhatsApp’s attempts to establish its new payments feature in both markets. These features were suspended by Brazil’s central bank and have been in testing in India for over two years. The good news is that regulators are paying attention. The pushback we’re seeing is not simply aversion to change, but industry experts exploring how these developments can keep consumer needs at the heart and enhance the current payment ecosystem. New business models and new players are important to keeping us all at the top of our game. Regulating a changing financial ecosystem We’re in a truly remarkable age, where the role of regulation is being tested again and again. I believe that regulators have a more vital role to play than ever. Covid-19 has been a powerful catalyst in the financial sector and there is some positive change to be harnessed from the disruption. If navigated shrewdly, regulators will succeed in capitalising on new trends to retain their core purpose: to ensure the safety and security of the customer and support positive change. The whole industry will need to work together closely to build a regulatory framework that is fertile for innovation and allows us to realise the enormous potential of payments in this new decade. So, what are we waiting for?

urn:contentItem:5XW3-R911-F021-640S-00000-00From Google's moonshot chief to BP's new boss: 10 people to watch in business in 20202019-12-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1From Google's moonshot chief to BP's new boss: 10 people to watch in business in 2020By Telegraph Reporters

Brexit, jittery markets and regulatory fears meant 2019 was a challenging year for many businesses in the UK and around the globe.

Whether 2020 will offer any more certainty remains to be seen, but firms will believe their best route to success will be forged by the people at the top. From experienced chief executives, regulatory titans and emerging entrepreneurs, here are our picks of the men and women who are likely to be shaking up the world of business in 2020.

Alison Rose

Rose is the first female chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland in its 300 year history and the first woman to run any of the UK's biggest four banks - RBS, HSBC, Barclays and Lloyds.

But the 50-year old, who succeeded Ross McEwan in November will be under pressure to make her mark on the taxpayer-controlled lender in 2020 as she embarks on her first full year on the job.

She will have to steer the bank through Brexit, reduce the government's stake in the bank and increase performance at RBS's small investment banking arm Natwest Markets. The lender is still 62pc-owned by the Treasury after a £46bn bailout in 2008.

Rose has worked at RBS for 27 years, previously serving as deputy chief executive of NatWest Holdings, the retail and commercial banking division, and running RBS's commercial and private banking business.

During her tenure, Rose has also fought to improve women's prospects in business, and was tasked by the Government with shedding light on the barriers faced by female entrepreneurs. In response to the The Alison Rose Review of Female Entrepreneurship, the Government pledged to increase the number of female entrepreneurs by half to nearly 600,000 women by 2030.

Lucy Burton

Mike Manley

The merger of FiatChrysler Automobiles (FCA) and Peugeot-owner PSA Groupe could put Mike Manley, the current chief executive of FCA, in a tricky position.

Terms of the deal will result in PSA boss Carlos Tavares heading the combined business, while the FCA chairman will take a similar position at the enlarged entity.

This is likely to make Manley, who took the top job at FCA when Sergio Marchionne stepped down shortly before his death in 2018, superfluous to requirements.

Although Elkann has said Manley "will be alongside" Tavares in the merged business, whether he will remain there is up for debate.

Highly respected for his organisational and operational abilities, Kent-born Manley-the most senior Briton in the global automotive industry-is seen by many as too powerful a force to be sidelined, and one deserving to head a car maker.

This could mean he's in the frame for the most prestigious job in the UK automotive industry-heading up JaguarLand Rover. Current chief executive Sir Ralf Speth is 64 and there has been speculation about how long he will remain in the job, having achieved his goal of overseeing the relaunch of the most iconic vehicle in the company's line-up: the new Defender.

It's by no means certain that Speth will go this year-he's steered JLR through good times and now rather tougher times-but, if he does, Manley could certainly be a potential replacement.

Alan Tovey

Margrethe Vestager

The European Union's "back again" competition commissioner says she has only just started, striking fear into the heart of Silicon Valley. The Danish politician and digital watchdog has earned a reputation as big tech's worst nightmare, fining Google $9bn for antitrust violations and Apple $14.5bn for tax avoidance.

And while she was expected to vacate her post in 2019, new European Commission president Ursula von der Layen confirmed Vestager would retain the competition brief and made her more powerful than ever. Vestager now has expanded oversight on the EU's digital policy and has pledged to crack down on some of the tech industry's worse excesses.

"In the last five years, some of the darker sides of digital technologies have become visible," Ms. Vestager said.

With her new remit, Vestager is set to introduce the world's first regulations on artificial intelligence and has called for collective bargaining rights for workers in the gig economy-such as Uber's drivers. She will also try to make companies pay more tax in Europe and will continue investigations into alleged unfair business practices by companies such as Apple, Amazon and Facebook.

But her wishlist will face challenges such as the UK's exit from the EU, fierce opposition from Silicon Valley itself and tetchy relations with the US. President Trump said of Vestager that "she hates the United States, perhaps worse than any person I have ever met".

And while big tech will be Vestager's main target in 2020, she will also be looking at wider competition issues, including the recent pledge to curb Chinese state-supported companies snapping up European assets.

Tom Hoggins

Trevor Strain

The heir apparent to David Potts to run Morrisons, the UK's third largest grocer. Strain, who spent three decades at rival Tesco before joining Morrisons in 2014, was promoted to chief operating officer in December.

He has long been tipped to succeed Potts, who previously spent 38 years at Tesco and took the helm at Morrisons in 2015.

Strain, a West Ham fan, had been finance chief since 2013. He has already had an insight into the top job when he was interim boss before Potts joined. As chief financial officer, Strain helped Morrison's through a troubled period in which the supermarket was under pressure to sell its stores and battle the rise of cheaper European rivals Aldi and Lidl.

The turnaround under Potts has seen the retailer record three straight years of profit and sales growth.

In his new role, Strain will take over responsibility for commercial, manufacturing, supply chain, logistics, operations development, online and wholesale. This second promotion in nine months is believed to be an attempt to prepare Strain for the top job.

And although Potts has played down suggestions he will retire, a reshuffle at the top is likely in 2020.

Laura Onita

Wendy Tan White

From South Kensington to Silicon Valley, Wendy Tan White is the woman behind Moonfruit (a website building business which she sold for £23m in 2012).

White is settling into the sunnier climes of Mountain View, California at the highly secretive 'X' headquarters. X is Google parent company Alphabet's moonshot department, responsible for incubating Waymo driverless cars, the "Everyday Robot" and internet balloon project Loon.

White knows how to scale a business and, as X's new vice-president, will be working with high risk ideas and helping steer them to profitable, bona fide businesses in their own right.

Hopefully her British links will result in some Google cash flowing to researchers and entrepreneurs from the UK, too.

Margi Murphy

Bernard Looney

The suave and charismatic Irishman is set to take over from Bob Dudley as chief executive of oil giant BP in the new year, and will become boss at a critical juncture in the company's 100 year history.

Just a decade on from the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, one of the worst environmental disasters in history, and battered more recently by negative public sentiment spurred by the Extinction Rebellion movement, BP must decide now what kind of company it wants to be for the next 50 years.

Does it want to make money, or does it want to save the planet? Many believe it cannot do both.

Looney, 49, disagrees.

While he has yet to set out his agenda for the company, all indications point to a steely focus on addressing the central dilemma faced by all the oil majors: how to transition to an environmentally friendly business without destroying shareholder value.

Likely to take centre stage at the start of February, Looney will have the platform to announce his vision for the company in detail. What he says will likely shape the fortunes of one of the UK's biggest corporates for potentially decades to come.

Edward Clowes

Melinda Roylett

The new UK general manager of Uber was appointed in August amid the controversy of London's ban on the ride-hailing app. A task made all the tougher by TfL's determination to see through the ban that could could remove Uber drivers from the capital's streets in early 2020.

Uber said that the ban is "extraordinary and wrong" and Roylett's main challenge will be to get on the right side of TfL and have the ride-hailing app restored in one of its most popular cities-task that will prove crucial to Uber's business as a whole.

But Roylett, who joined the Silicon Valley after a stint as head of Europe at payment company Square and ten years at Paypal, also has Uber's other UK pursuits to expand.

She will be responsible for the ride-hailing app's presence in 40 cities across the UK and Ireland and will be determined to stave off any further regulatory threats, as well as competition from emerging rivals such as Bolt.

Hannah Boland

John Malone

The "Cable Cowboy" John Malone is the kingmaker in the UK telecoms market in 2020. His cable group Liberty Global, the owner of Virgin Media, has more than $11bn burning a hole in its pocket following the sale of its German business to Vodafone.

Much of the cash is likely to be returned to Liberty Global shareholders, but most industry watchers also expect Malone to buy a UK mobile operator so that Virgin Media can challenge BT in the emerging market for "converged" connectivity packages bundling home broadband with wireless service.

O2, owned by the Spanish giant Telefonica, is viewed as the most likely candidate. The main question is how Malone, a fan of complex financial engineering, could structure a deal using Virgin Media's valuable tax losses-or even with a stock market listing that could allow the 78-year-old Colorado billionaire to continue what has been a gradual withdrawal from European telecoms.

Virgin Media, which is on track to lose its longstanding network advantage as the Government encourages new rival full-fibre infrastructure, is also wooing Sky for a potential broadband wholesale deal that could deliver a heavy blow to BT's Openreach network arm.

Malone has never been one to let his yearnings get ahead of his earnings, but his decisions this year are crucial to Britain's connected future.

Christopher Williams

Brian Chesky

AirBnB's chief executive has gone from renting out his apartment and blow-up mattresses to the cusp of one of the world's hottest business floats.

The wildly successful property start-up provides cheap accommodation by letting anyone rent out their spare room and, after its relatively low-key beginnings in San Francisco, is now active in cities across the globe, and is reporting revenues north of $2bn.

Chesky announced plans for AirBnB to go public in September, with the 38-year-old New Yorker looking to break the trend of WeWork-style calamitous listings. Chesky is worth a reported $4.2bn himself, with AirBnB looks set to command a huge valuation in 2020.

But despite its success, the company is still walking a tightrope, with regulatory concerns over unscrupulous landlords taking advantage of AirBnB's platform to essentially run unregulated hotels. If local authorities begin to crack down on this behaviour, AirBnB's seemingly healthy business could look more questionable. How Chesky balances the concerns will be one of the more compelling storylines of 2020.

Tom Hoggins

The mystery members of Facebook's new supreme court

We do not know their names. We do not know their faces. All we know is that there will be at least 20 of them - and that in 2020 they will begin deciding some of the internet's most controversial free speech cases.

These are the yet-to-be-appointed members of Facebook's new Oversight board, which will soon begin operating as an independent court of appeal for its 2.4bn users.

The board is intended to take pressure off Facebook itself, but it will likely draw down intense scrutiny upon the judges' backgrounds, biases and arguments, and the company is concerned enough about their safety that it is drawing up a special security plan.

One thing is certain: they can't please everyone.

Laurence Dodds

urn:contentItem:54X1-76J1-JBF5-T081-00000-00From Google to Facebook, online privacy concerns aren't going away (infographic)2012-02-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom Googleto Facebook, online privacy concerns aren't going away (infographic)

Ever since Googleannounced its new, controversial privacy policy two weeks ago, interest in online privacy has spiked as more people question how Googleand other companies are managing their data.

Googleannounced last week that it would change its privacy policy by combining 60 existing policies into one, with the changes going into effect March 1. While simplification of hard-to-read policies is nice, Googleattracted criticism because it will now combine user data across all of its services, including search, Gmail, YouTube, Google+, and GoogleDocs. First the U.S. Congress voiced concerns about the changes, and on Friday, European regulators jumped into the privacy dog pile.

Googleisn't the only big tech company being scrutinized. Facebook, which controls (and sells) an incredible amount of data people voluntarily submit, has also attracted the eye of the regulators in the U.S. and abroad. In a huge November settlement with the social media company, the Federal Trade Comission found Facebook's privacy practices from 2009 to be deceptive and in violation of federal law. In 2009, Facebookset friends lists, photos, and other info to a default publicly visible setting, even if the person had already designated that info for friends only. The company has since hired two privacy officers and given more notice to users when changes are happening, as it did with the Timeline feature.

Keeping track of all these privacy issues can be challenging, but this infographic by Frugal Dad outlines some of the biggest privacy problems that have come up in the past few years. More importantly, the infographic also outlines some important ways to protect yourself online, including changing passwords frequently, using more caution with public computers, and turning on cookie notices.

Take a look at the full infographic:

Filed under: security

urn:contentItem:5P2T-NX81-DY0W-43XC-00000-00From Health Care To Taxes; Balloon Triggers Explosion; More Trouble For Chipotle; Pushing Ahead To Tax Reform; Discovery-Scripps Merger?;2017-07-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom Health Care To Taxes; Balloon Triggers Explosion; More Trouble For Chipotle; Pushing Ahead To Tax Reform; Discovery-Scripps Merger?;LanhamFULL TEXT

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: -- get something done and it's going to be very good but Obamacare is a big failure.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: McConnell plans to hold a vote to repeal Obamacare early next week. Four GOP senators currently disprove of the effort. It does not look like he has the votes there. Shocking video out of California to show you. The details after a balloon causes a massive explosion and power outage. And new trouble for Chipotle this morning. The company forced to close a restaurant in Virginia after several customers felt severely ill. The fallout ahead as the stock continues to trade down. Morgan Stanley, the name to watch this morning on Wall Street. The bank reported second quarter earnings that were above expectations. The stock is up better than two percent. Morgan is also racing its quarterly dividend this morning by 25 percent.

Take a look futures this morning and we are looking at a mixed opening for the broader average. The Dow is down largely due to IBM. IBM dragging on the Dow after reporting another decline in quarterly revenue. Earnings are better than expected but revenue is below estimates. Once again, IBM stock is lower. The NASDAQ is up, that's up about 10 points. So we will see some winners today. In Europe stocks are searching for direction. Take a look at the Eurozone indices this morning and you see strength across the board but just fractionally so. The FT 100 and the CAC quarante up a quarter of a percent a piece. In Asia overnight, markets closed higher with the best performer. In China, the Shanghai Composite up one and a third percent.

All those stories coming this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal's Global Economic Editor Jon Hilsenrath, and Fox News Contributor and republican strategist, Mercedes Schlapp. Great show everybody.

MERCEDES SCHLAPP, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: My pleasure.

JON HILSENRATH, GLOBAL ECONOMICS EDITOR, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Great to be here.

MANSELL: We want to get in to tax reform today. That's where the focus seems to want to go after health care.

HILSENRATH: Right. End of the year, it's the homestretch they - that's where the victory is going to come from for republicans.

SCHLAPP: I hope you're right. I'm hoping that they can move on the tax reform and see if they can push this through but there's still open questions on border-adjustment tax and how they're going to pay for it, it's going to be a revenue neutral bill or is it not?

BARTIROMO: We're talking about that right now. Joining the conversation momentarily is House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady in the studio with us this morning. Also with us is International Brotherhood of Teamsters president, James Hoffa who is very vocal saying he did not want to see that health care bill come to fruition. Also joining us, George Senator David Perdue is here, and the host of Varney & Company, Stuart Varney will weigh in. As well, you don't want to miss a moment of it, so do stay with us. Big hour coming up.

Our top story right now this hour, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says a vote to is to foresee with the GOP's health care bill will be held early next week. This as the administration shifts its focus to tax reform. Blake Burman is at the White House this morning with all the latest. Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Maria. Dood morning to you as a well. And that vote that you just referenced next week is not expected to lead to any sort of breakthrough. Here is the reality right now for senate republicans here in Washington. They do not have the votes to repeal Obamacare now and replace it a couple years down the line. They also do not have the votes as it stands at this moment to repeal and replace Obamacare now. So yesterday, here at the White House, President Trump suggested that the next best path going forward just might be to let Obamacare implode.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I think we're probably in that position where we just let Obamacare fail, we're not going to own it. I'm not going own it. I can tell you the republicans are not going to own it. We'll let Obamacare fail and then the democrats are going to come to us and they're going to say, how do we fix it? How do we fix it? Or, how do we come up with a new plan?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The administration though is not yet conceding that health care reform is dead. Vice President Pence implored yesterday that, "Inaction is not an option." The plan all along, Maria, as you know has been to repeal Obamacare, to allow for the largest tax cuts possible and the vice president yesterday continued to outline some pretty lofty expectations.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're going to cut taxes across the board for working families, small businesses, and family farms. We're going to simplify the tax code by cutting seven brackets down to three. We'll eliminate the alternative minimum tax, we'll make the code flatter and fairer and simpler for everyone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The vice president, Maria, also reiterated yesterday that they want a business tax rate of 15 percent, but here is where everything stands out this moment here in Washington. Right now, health care reform is mired in neutral, the budget resolution which could lead to reconciliation that republicans want to use for tax reform even that resolution, Maria, is facing some pushback from conservatives already in the house. Maria, back to you.

BARITROMO: All right, Blake. Thank you so much. Blake Burman is at the White House. I want to bring in House Committee on Ways and Means Chairman and Texas Congressman, Kevin Brady is with us right now. Congressman, it's good to see you.

REP. KEVIN BRADY (R-TX), HOUSE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. So, let's talk about where you begin now. How critical is the passage of tax reform following the latest setback on the health care overhaul? We're going to get to the budget first but this is incredibly critical.

BRADY: Yes. So the sure answer is even more critical than ever. Look, we got to get this gone going in a big way. This is a major - we're continuing to see companies move offshore, we're just not seeing the economic growth. There are so many young people have no opportunities when they leave school. And so, we have to deliver on this and obviously with - - there is no way to spin in a good way what happened in the senate this week. It doesn't make it easier but I'll tell you what, we're on pace to deliver in 2017. Getting distracted isn't an option for us. In fact, we've run this parallel to second track on tax reform nearly since the day after President Trump was elected. So -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And I know you've been having meetings side-by-side as you've been affording health care but how are you going to do it, Congressman? I mean, let's face it, looks what you're up against here. You don't have any democratic support, you've got real divisions within the republican party. First, you've got to get through the budget, so tell me what's going on today in terms of budget reconciliation to give you that green white towards tax reform?

BRADY: Yes. So today is really important because the budget committee led by Chairwoman Diane Black who's doing a remarkable job, gives it - the passage today in the committee, gives us the green light, vehicle to deliver tax reform. This year, the president's desk is critical, this is not a normal budget because this is in effect the tax reform budget and really important, so today matters.

BARITROMO: All right. Today matters. What are you going to do in terms of all of the divisions? We saw the divisions in health care and we know that there's still debate within the tax conversation, border-adjustment tax, deductions, what stays, what goes away. Are you still married to the border-adjustment tax?

BRADY: So I'm married to solving the problem of stopping companies from moving offshore and more importantly trading right incentives for bringing those supply chains helm and that's where the White House and the republicans all. We are all focused on solving that problem. At the end of the day, whether border-adjustment is part that solution or whether it set aside for future study and we - and agreed on alternative, we're going to solve that problem of offshoring in a positive way.

BARTIROMO: So, do you need revenue in a tax reform package? Do you need some form of revenue whether it's border-adjustment tax or something else, maybe a higher corporate tax rate than we're talking about?

BRADY: Well, so we want to make this permanent. We really think we're going for the long game here. Make sure the decisions business is makes to reinvest in the U.S. are certain for them and so that requires us to balance within the budget over 10 years. We can do that but we got to make some serious trade-offs or at least we have to be creative as we're thinking about how we lower the rates. So, we've got to all of that.

BARTIROMO: What are the trade-offs, Congressman?

BRADY: Well, you just got to look at where the revenue comes from in the tax code. And bottom line is, we have to ask you ourselves a basic question, for us to become competitive again, to leapfrog back into lead worldwide so companies can compete and win anywhere in the world including here at home, we need the permanence in the lowest rates possible. And that means we have to think about jettisoning specific provisions to benefit some, so we can lower the rates to become competitive for all and that's always the challenge in tax reform. In final point, all these debates, whether it's border-adjustment or interest, these are healthy debates.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BRADY: This is exactly what we ought to be having in this discussion.

BARTIROMO: They were all healthy debates, it was healthy debates on health care as well. What do you do for Medicaid, what do you o do for big governments? I get that.

BRADY: So I think the difference here in lessons learn from health care is the fact that president agreed to work with the house and senate on a unified, a single tax reform plan and then put it put into work President Trump, in his team, we're putting the work right now on this. I think this is time well spent and increases our chance for success issue.

BARTIROMO: Let's educate our viewers on exactly what you're looking for from them in in terms of their individual rates because a moment ago you said to me, look, when you talk about the trade-offs, you have to yourself where does the revenue come from. It isn't sure that much of the revenue is coming from individual tax rates.

BRADY: Well, on the business -

BARTIROMO: You want to lower them.

BRADY: So, on the individual side, clearly, we are proposing the simpler fair system, somewhat, so nine out of ten Americans will be able to file using postcards system. So we're asking that question, how fair and how low do you want your rates to go? On the business side, really I think there is broad agreement, broaden the base, lower the rate, become far more competitive than we are today. And the work that we're doing with the White House and senate, I'll just tell you this, I really like the pace and substance of what we're discussing right now. I think this time both the tax teams and the principals in the White House and senate, these are exactly discussions you want us to be having to come to unified plan.

BARTIROMO: So the individual tax rates, you'd like it to be three brackets?

BRADY: Yes. If possible I think that's --

BARTIROMO: What are the rates that you - that you would favor?

BRADY: So we proposed a 12, 25, and 33 rate in the house blueprint. The Trump team in original tax plan, very close to that. And so we started with very solid common ground on the individual rate.

BARTIROMO: But now there is discussion that - look, it looks bad if you cut rates on the rich. That maybe you lose 39.6 percent where it is which is the current top rate in terms of individual tax. Your thoughts.

BRADY: Yes. I'm not one of those guys. I think we need to go for growth, that's what we want in this tax code up and down the line and lowering rates for Americans regardless of where they're at is pro-growth, encouraging more savings investment for Americans is awfully pro-growth, and the business side as well. We do this right, I think we unlock the economy in a major way.

BARTIROMO: On the he corporate side, President Trump has talked about a 15 percent rate, there's no way you're going to get a 15 percent rate isn't that right?

BRADY: So, this goes as low as we can go. I mean, that's our goal.

BARTIROMO: What do you think? 20, 22 percent?

BRADY: Well, look, we proposed 20 in the house blueprint, that's our goal, continues to be our goal in this - in this discussion.

BARTIROMO: Because there's some businesspeople who say, look, going from 35 to 25 is going to be a yawn, it's just not going to move the needle very much.

BRADY: We are not doing tax reform so we can leapfrog to the middle.

BARTIROMO: OK.

BRADY: So that we can leapfrog to be merely average. There is no reason to do this, so we still the bolder we go on the rates and how we unlock that business investment to expensing we think is really critical.

BARTIROMO: There is a lot of debate in terms of the deductions, so what are sacred cows in your view? I mean, you've said that you would favor keeping the charitable deduction in place, is that right?

BRADY: Yes. So I will think -

BARTIROMO: What else?

BRADY: On the postcard, we're proposing keeping no mortgage deductions and charitable deduction. It was cultural type of incentives and we're looking -- taking a fresh look at how we can incentivize more charitable giving for example across the income spectrum. We keep the child tax credit and the college credit. In fact we're redesigning that, so we can encourage more use of it for technical schools. Welding, plumbing, all those skills we really need in America and we keep the credit to help you keep people from welfare to work. We think those are critical elements of the postcard but we're also listening, we're listening to lawmakers, we're listening to stakeholders on what exactly they want on that postcard and still keeping the rates low.

BARTIROMO: So what happens when you're up against, say Congressman Peter King who will say, I am not going to buy into anything that eliminates the deduction for property. My constituents are paying $30,000 in property taxes every year. $40,000, something like that. I mean, how are you going to negotiate when you've got a sacred cows elsewhere that you want to get rid of and there are some of your colleagues on the right who say, I can't - I can't vote a for that.

BRADY: Yes. So there is no question. We can keep this status quo. We can keep New York's tax rates effectively over 44 percent and keep state and local sales tax deductions, that's not a problem. Or we can lower those rates substantially and let all Americans including New Yorkers pay their local -- state and local taxes but have a net tax cut as we do it. And I think at the end of the day, people are going to opt for lower rates far simpler code and everyone just sort of use the dollars, the savings to get to their priorities.

BARTIROMO: If you don't get health care done, I mean we're talking about another vote next week which people are saying you don't have the votes to actually do the repeal next week. If health care does not get done, what do you end up doing? Do you just cut taxes or what?

BRADY: So from -- look, I think it's incredibly important for the senate individual republicans to stay at table until they solve this problem. In my district, Obamacare is collapsing. You know, this really isn't an option to do nothing. So I hope they continue to do it but from tax standpoint, look, I want those taxes -- health care, taxes on the economy. If that doesn't happen, we're moving forwarding anyway regardless on tax reform.

BARTIROMO: Real quick. When do you expect we will actually see the bread and butter here in terms of tax reform?

BRADY: Yes. So, I think Fall is the timetable for delivering in 2017. You know, I've gotten away from specific dates on this stuff. Let's get the policy right, let's deliver this year. We still have some work to do, obviously in all this -- in the tax discussions but again, I think people are going to like the boldness and permanence of this plan.

BARTIROMO: Do you get any support - any participation from democrats?

BRADY: We do. We're having discussions with, house democrats and centrist democrats about tax reform. We welcome their ideas. Look, their economies are struggling too.

BARTIROMO: Mr. Chairman, thank you so much for walking us through it.

BRADY: Thank, Maria.

BARTIROMO: We know we'll have some time with you in the month of August --

(CROSSTALK)

BRADY: Yes. Looking forward to that.

BARTIROMO: Chairman Brady. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARITROMO: Welcome back. Chipotle giving another food scare, Lea Gabrielle in New York with the story. Lea?

LEA GABRILLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria. Well, people do love those options they can get at Chipotle but now they're getting sick. The company temporary closed a restaurant on Sterling, Virginia on Monday after several people reported getting sick there. Chipotle blames an outbreak of Norovirus which the company says did not come from its food supply adding that (INAUDIBLE) of the chain. Chipotle was of course hit by a number of food safety issues two years ago which is caused it failed and stock to plunge and in fact, shares of Chipotle fell more than 4 percent yesterday and they are remaining under pressure this morning in premarket trading.

Well, check this out. A dramatic image caught on camera, look at that, a Mylar balloon making contact with the power line. That's what happened, that happened right there in Long Beach, California triggering an intense explosion between two homes. Well, the blast caused a power outage in the area for hours. Officials of course have long warned to the public about the danger Mylar balloons pose to power lines and now you can see exactly what happened.

Well, two television networks are in merger talks. They are Discovery and Scripps and they're discussing a deal that would put Animal Planet and Food Network under one roof. Well, the two media companies are trying to chart a course in cable -- in the cable T.V. industry which is just being - being caught upside down really by digital consumption. So terms of the deal are unknown. Discovery is worth 15 billion and Scripps has a nine-billion market valuation. The companies have talked about merging since 2014.

And Morgan Stanley's latest quarterly results coming in better-than- expected. Boosted by strength in its investment banking and its wealth management businesses. And they also raised its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share. The stock is higher ahead of the opening bell. Maria?

BARITROMO: All right, Lea. Thank you so much. The stock up three percent, of course, IBM is down and that's weighing on the markets a bit. We'll take a break. When we come back, putting American workers first. The Trump administration in middle of renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement. Labor Leader James Hoffa will join me with what he wants to see from the NAFTA deal. And IBM reports declining revenue for the 21st quarter in a row. Disappointing sales chipping away confidence in the technology giant. Stock is down almost three percent right now. What weighed down the company's results? We'll check it out after this break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARITROMO: Welcome back. We are coming to you live from our nation's capital this morning, talking about jobs, trade, the American worker. On that front, the administration says, reducing trade deficit is the top priority for renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement also known as NAFTA with Canada and Mexico. U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer says, an updated agreement will also include a digital economy chapter and fold in labor and environmental obligations. Joining me right now in an exclusive interview to weigh in is the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, James Hoffa. Great to see you, James.

JAMES HOFFA, PRESIDENT, INTERNATIONAL BROTHERHOOD OF TEAMSTERS: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us this morning. So what do you want to see - what's most important to see in this redo of NAFTA from your standpoint?

HOFFA: Well, I talked to the ambassador yesterday and we talked about what the priorities are and we watch over a million jobs have gone there. We've got to start getting those jobs back, we've got to have a fair trade agreement, we've got to have one that has content with regard to automobiles built there. We want to have more jobs back here. We started that process, the president started out. Remember when he talked about Ford motor? They basically canned a two-billion-dollar operation and brought it back here. We need more of that to basically reenergize the economy and get those million jobs back. But more than that, we've got to basically have a NAFTA that's fair, that basically controls Mexican trucks that are coming into our country, that are unsafe. We've got to have one that has a good resolution process, that's fair, that doesn't happen right now. So there is a lot to do here and the ambassador is very excited about getting there and we're going to be working with him and we think we're off to a great start.

BARTIROMO: One of the issues with NAFTA was that once that deal happened, it became OK for a company to say, oh, I'm going to go build in Mexico and have all of this cheap labor and I'm just going to sell back to the U.S. And deal after deal to sort of -- that was the template. Isn't that right?

HOFFA: Absolutely right. We were not sold that. Did anybody when they - when NAFTA happened in the 90s with Clinton, did anybody think that all these corporations were going to move across the border and basically lay off Americans? Did anybody think that? No. We weren't sold that and that's exactly what's happened here. I can go through 100 companies, every union can go through a hundred companies that have closed, move down there, Mr. Coffee, Square D, closer plants, move down there, laid off the Americans, make the same product, bring it back here. That's not what this was about. We've got to change that, make it fair, and I think we're off to a good start and I'm looking forward to working with the ambassador. Make it fair but also this stuff is expensive. How do you do it without fuss in the debt? I want to turn to health care in talking about what's important for American workers. The International Brotherhood of Teamsters sent this letter to - from yourself and Ken Hall saying that you were against the better care reconciliation act of 2017. What was your biggest problem with it?

HOFFA: Well, the problem is it's dead right now. I mean, they tried to do it, the republicans tried to do it with 52 people in the senate, they didn't - they didn't make it. And they're going to have to start reaching out to the other side. I think, you know, what happened with Obamacare is a good example what's going to happen with the budget, what's going to happen with everything. They can't do it by themselves, they don't control their 52 people with Merekowski and Collins and other people. So they're going to have to have a different approach to the budget, they're going to have to have a different approach to health care. Health care is dead right now, I mean, we're going to have Obamacare, that's going to be the law of the land, that's not changing, that -- the way it is.

BARTIROMO: Do you think it will implode?

HOFFA: No. Well, if they keep trying to kill it, it will. I mean, you can kill anything.

BARTIROMO: But I mean, even - putting the republicans aside, I mean, you don't have any choice right now, you haven't had choice in a while, you got these big insurance companies saying, I'm out of here, I lost a billion dollars on Obamacare. So it is imploding regardless of what's going in the republic.

HOFFA: I think the problem is they have to reach - you have to be serious about saving it. They have to get with the - with the democrats to figure out how we fix it, but they need more money. You can't keep on standing on the air hose and basically think people are going to survive and that's what's happening. They're saying, we want it to die, we're going to cut money off and that's what's going on with these companies. You got to make an incentive to do it. There's going to be more money to take care of the most vulnerable people.

BARTIROMO: Did the ambassador respond in terms of what you were looking for NAFTA?

HOFFA: He did. He talked about it and we're, you know, focusing on workers, focusing on the problems and we have so many problems in the Teamsters which other trucks coming in here. But we also talked about basically fairness, he's got some good ideas and we're going to sit down with him with other labor leaders, we serve on ACPEN, a number of committees that work with the ambassador on NAFTA. So we're excited about what we're doing.

BARTIROMO: It sounds like you've had a voice. The Teamsters have had a voice in some of these policy plans. How is President Trump doing so far with his promise to create jobs in America and help workers like the Teamsters?

HOFFA: Absolutely. He ran as a populist. He's got to stay on that message. He can't get diverted and all the things going on in diverting him. He talked about, you know, getting on a TPP. He talked to about pipeline, he did that. He talked about carrier insurance, keeping those jobs in America. People want that. He's got to get back on that message and don't get hijacked on others things about - other things that he is doing that are distracting him whether into Russia or whatever. You got to get back on the focus there and that's going to be the focus with the budget and things that are going to be coming out in the next couple of months.

BARTIROMO: But I mean, you know, the media is all over the Russia story, the left is trying to obstruct. What are your thoughts about how the democrats are basically saying, no, we don't want this agenda executed. We're going to put as much noise as possible in the room so that they agenda does not get executed.

HOFFA: Well, they're not doing that with regard to - with regard to jobs, we're doing it with regard to some of the ideas, you know, tax cuts for the rich, that's the problem. That's not going to work.

BARTIROMO: Are you saying tax reform is all about tax cuts for the rich?

HOFFA: That's what it' about. Right. That's what it's about.

BARTIROMO: Come on. Give me a break.

HOFFA: That's what it's about.

BARTIROMO: They're taking - we just heard from Kevin Brady. He said, three brackets that he wants.

HOFFA: You know, did you know that General Electric is embowing.

BARTIROMO: -- They're taking rates all the way down you for individuals.

HOFFA: Didn't pay any taxes, did you know that?

BARTIROMO: I'm sorry?

HOFFA: They didn't pay any taxes. Some of these big corporations, this billion-dollar corporation are not paying taxes.

BARTIROMO: Because of all the deductions, that's another thing he want to do, to get rid of all the deductions so that it's clean slate.

HOFFA: We've got to close up all these - got to close these loopholes.

BARTIROMO: Right. And that's what he's saying he's going to do. So you're happy with the tax reform package on the docket now or you think it cuts for the rich?

HOFFA: Well, it's tax cuts for the rich right now. 40 percent of the tax cuts go to one percent. We've got to have that, that's not fair to America right now.
