BARTIROMO: Let's take a break. We're going to talk about tackling tax reform this morning. We're talking with one small business owner about her fight to cut the corporate tax rate. Will it happen this year?

And then Rosie O'Donnell sparking outrage after promoting a game where users push President Trump off of a cliff, the controversy, next, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Here again is Maria Bartiromo with a special edition with MORNINGS WITH MARIA live from Washington, D.C.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good Wednesday morning, everybody, welcome back, thanks so much for being here. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, July 19th. Your top stories right now 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Time to tackle tax reform. After pulling the Senate Health Care Bill, Republicans turned their attention to overhauling the tax code. They'll have plenty of support from Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY: It has been over three decades since we attacked reform in this country. This is too long and this administration is committed to changing this. On the business side, we have one of the most complicated systems in the world. We tax on worldwide income with our system deferral. It is not surprising that trillions of dollars are left overseas. We want to bring back those profits with a lower business rate so that companies can invest in America.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, we're speaking with House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Kevin Brady, this morning as the committee's tax policy subcommittee prepares for a hearing in overhauling the tax code later today.

Rosie O'Donnell is rekindling her rivalry with President Trump, but did she go too far? The outrage over the new game from the comedian, allowing players to push the President off of a cliff. Chipotle wrapped up in another food scare, the stock hit hard after a possible norovirus outbreak in a location in Virginia. The company's response to this latest setback.

And markets are looking higher this morning. Take a look at Futures indicating a gain at the opening of trading for S&P 500 and the NASDAQ. The NASDAQ is up a quarter of a percent right now, 15 points higher. The Dow Jones Industrial Average just slipping into negative territory, it is down eight points, fractional move there.

In Europe, stocks are mostly higher. Take a look at the European indices right now, and we're looking at a live situation here. FT-100 and CAC Quarante up a fraction, the DAX Index in Germany flat, down a fraction. In Asia overnight, markets closed higher with the best performer there in China. Shanghai Composite up 1-1/3 percent.

Well, sorry, Justin Bieber, there is a new king at the top of the charts. The runway hit that's taking the title of most streamed song ever with over 4.6 billion plays. We'll tell you about it. First, though, our top story right now this half an hour, the fight for meaningful tax reform. With the failure of the Senate Health Care Bill, top Republicans are now focusing efforts on overhauling the tax code. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady believes that Congress can still get this done and get it done quickly.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KEVIN BRADY (R-TX), HOUSE WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: We're still shooting for the lowest rates possible, the most competitive design we can and lowering those tax rates whether you're a local business person or a middle-class family. And so, I haven't seen anything yet that knocks us off our pace to deliver it this year.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is the former police officer and DGG Uniform & Work Apparel President, Teresa Meares. Teresa, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

TERESA MEARES, PRESIDENT, DGG UNIFORM & WORK APPAREL: Good morning, thank you.

BARTIROMO: You're a small business owner. We want to talk about tax reform from your standpoint, from a small business owner's standpoint, but you testified about tax reform last week in front of the House Ways and Means Tax Committee. The tax policy subcommittee, as a small business owner, what was your message to Congress?

MEARES: Well, our message was that you need to have a conversation with a lot of small businesses and you need to do a reform and now is the time to do it. So, we were very passionate and had the opportunity to share our personal stories on how it affected us. So, hopefully, it'll help move them along.

BARTIROMO: So, tell us your personal story, how does it affect you?

MEARES: So, as a -- as a small business, I file as an S corp., so I -- my important message was to make sure that they do keep that in there. I know I hear a lot of talk about between the C Corp and the S Corp and the pass- throughs. And that's what I file as. And when I first started my business in 2006, I had rapid growth and I added, you know, employees very quickly and I had to buy a lot of equipment and grow my business. And at that point, the lack of simplification on the tax actually cost me to overpay taxes during those critical years that I needed that cash. So, you know, that alone was very difficult for me as a small business and create a challenge.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Teresa, it's Dagen McDowell, do you think that politicians with even your local lawmakers are listening to you?

MEARES: You know, I sure hope so. I definitely think that they're listening to us. The only challenge that I see at this point is that people are getting distracted, and they have their own interests at heart, but I encourage all small business owners to reach out to their local Congressmen and let them know how it affects them personally. It's important upon us. Politicians, the House can help push this through but it's -- small businesses need to get vocal and they need to get involved and they need to understand how it affects them so that way they can voice it to their representatives.

MERCEDES SCHLAPP, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CONTRIBUTOR: Teresa, this is Mercedes, one quick question. So, we know that the House -- the Senate Bill on the health care reform pretty much is dead at this point. How does that impact your small business in terms of the health care cost?

MEARES: Well, I mean, it's obviously impacted my business as far as cost and the insurance premiums as well. So, I was a little disappointed to see that. The bright side of it would be maybe everybody can refocus on the tax reform and we can at least get that pushed through.

BARTIROMO: So, your tax rate right now is 35 percent?

MEARES: Thirty-five percent, yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And you'd like to see this obviously go down to 15 percent. If we were to see rates go down to the 20 percent range, they're talking about 20 to 22, 25 percent. What does that going to do in terms of your behavior? With that extra money that you're saving, are you going to be investing in your business? Are you going to be hiring new workers? What are your expansion plans?

MEARES: Yes. Absolutely. I sold my -- one of my businesses last year and then I relaunched another business and I'm growing. I just hired five new employees in the last six months. So, I'm on fast pace to grow my company, and I need that cash to help me grow. When I get to the point where, you know, I'm not break even and I get to that profitability, alone, I figured it was just a 10 percent reduction that I would have $60,000 to $80,000 to reinvest back into my company.

MCDOWELL: Teresa, in terms of how the economy looks to you right now, I mean, do you get a sense of its strengths, any weaknesses that you worry about?

MEARES: You know, I do think the economy is responding right now, but I think everyone is very hesitant because they don't know what is or is not going to pass. So, I feel that everyone is a little cautious right now until we can get some solid ground to stand on and some permanents on some things.

BARTIROMO: So, aside from the tax rate, are there any other must-haves in this tax reform bill that lawmakers are talking about right now that will move the needle in terms of growth for small business?

MEARES: Well, I think simplification and reduction are probably the two most important tax reforms that they need to address.

SCHLAPP: Do you think that President Trump is keeping to his commitment of pushing for economic growth? Do you think that he's being able to sell that message?

MEARES: I do. I think he is trying to do that, and I think everyone is trying to figure out how to work together to get that done. And I truly do hope that the bipartisan comes into play and that they're able to look at the small businesses because as you go down the road just sitting in the passenger seat and you look out the window, you just see small business after small business after small business, and that is what makes the employment number move, and we're the ones that are the backbone of America, so you have to do something for us.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's been frustrating that we haven't really seen this tax package get traction because we're awaiting on health care. Let me add on to what Mercedes asked you in terms of the health care implications from your standpoint, how are you impacted by this setback in terms of the health care overhaul?

MEARES: Well, I mean, I'm not really impacted right now because it's been in effect so I'm status quo. You know, I offer insurance to my employees and I also pay 50 percent of the premium. If it doesn't, you know, get improved or passed or reduced, then I'm going to have to reduce that, and that's actually going to take more money out of my employees' pocket. And I can't give them a raise and I'm going to have to take more out of their paycheck to help pay for the health insurance, so that's how it will impact it. It would impact my employees a lot more.

BARTIROMO: Sure. The -- you know, something has to give. Now, the tax policy subcommittee, you testified before last week, will hold another hearing today. This on simplifying the tax code to help individuals and families. You say that this is critical, the simplification. You want three brackets?

MEARES: I do. I think it's simplification and approach to that is the most important because like I said, in my early years of growing, when I had the profitability, I overpaid in taxes, and nobody should have to do that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, this is important.

MCDOWELL: Teresa, my issue is because we are both the children of small business owners and literally our entire lives we've heard politicians given lip service to people who own and operate small businesses in this country. And right now, as it stands because health care -- repeal of Obamacare would -- and the replacement would really help small business owners as will tax reform, but do you think that these politicians truly understand what it's like to go to work every morning and operate a business just like you do?

MEARES: Well, I think some do because when I testified in front of the subcommittee last week, there was probably three to five of them that all came from small business. So, you know, it's interesting that small business owners get involved in politics is because they get frustrated with what is happening and what they have to cut -- carry. So, I do think that there are some that understand it, and as I said earlier, it really is upon the small businesses to stand up and start voicing what is it that does or does not affect you. Because you have to look at the sectors, too, you know, what may help my business may not help a farm business, may not help a manufacturing company. So, we need to understand it from everyone's perspective.

BARTIROMO: What if the tax reform doesn't get done this year, what if they just cut taxes in a simple way because they can't get health care done, impact to small business?

MEARES: Yes, as it always has been. You know, I mean, we're surviving but it's not fun and we're at a point where, you know, something has to give. So, I think you'll see some frustration. I think you'll see some people that will -- may not try to continue or grow their business and that would hurt employment numbers and it would definitely hurt the economy.

BARTIROMO: We'll leave it there. Teresa, thanks so much for sharing your story, we appreciate it.

MEARES: All right, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Teresa Meares joining us there. I'll sit down with House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Kevin Brady, coming up to talk tax reform coming up at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Join us for the early plans of what he's expecting from a tax reform package.

Coming up, a massive recall for Mercedes-Benz parent company Daimler over emission concerns, the latest following rival Volkswagen's crisis as well.

And then other smartphone makers joining Apple's fight against chipmaker Qualcomm. The legal battle heating up, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Wednesday morning. Futures are pointing to a mixed opening for the broader averages today. Take a look at the market. Dow Industrials down about nine points; S&P 500 and NASDAQ in positive territory. NASDAQ looks good up 13 points right now.

A couple of names on the move, Qualcomm, a NASDAQ company, it is reporting third-quarter results after the bell tonight. Analysts are expecting earnings of $0.81 a share. It comes under the company's growing battle against Apple and other smartphone makers. Last night, several manufacturers including Foxconn announced plans to file a lawsuit against Qualcomm for illegal patent licensing practices. Qualcomm shares are down better than 13 percent year to date.

American Express also said to report after the close for the quarterly numbers. Investors are expecting $1.43 a share on $8.2 billion in revenue at Amex. Amex shares are up 33 percent in the last 52 weeks.

Well, Rosie O'Donnell's new tweets against President Trump is sparking widespread outrage this morning. Lea Gabrielle in New York with the details -- Lea.

LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Well, hi, Maria. You know, Rosie O'Donnell and President Trump have such a rosy relationship. Yes, Ms. O'Donnell tweeted, quote, "Push Trump off a cliff again." Her tweet links to an online game where players can make a virtual President Trump jump off a cliff. Users can also send the character down a manhole, into a volcano, or into the jaws of a T-rex, very nice.

Meantime, German automaker, Daimler, is updating software of more than 3 million Mercedes amid investigations that it cheated on emissions. That move comes as regulators and criminal investigators on both sides of the Atlantic are scrutinizing Mercedes-Benz on suspicion that some of its diesel vehicles cheated on emissions standards.

And a song that is now in the history books just six months after its release.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GABRIELLE: Universal Music Latin Entertainment says Despacito has become the most streamed song of all-time, playing more than 4.6 billion times across streaming platforms. The track by Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee and featuring Justin Bieber, breaking the record previously set by Bieber for the 2015 hit, Sorry. Despacito has been at the top of the billboard hot 100 for 10 weeks. That's the beauty of streaming music, bringing cultures and languages together so everybody can boogie, Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, that's something. I'm still stuck on the Rosie O'Donnell story, Lea. Thank you very much. Promoting this game where Donald Trump gets pushed off a cliff, your take.

MCDOWELL: I -- that's exactly what I expect from Rosie O'Donnell.

BARTIROMO: That's -- OK. It's your point.

MCDOWELL: They have a -- they have a long-running feud -- they have a long-running feud, and she -- and I think that all of these people who go after President Trump, that they want his attention. They like and they love a negative attention especially somebody like Rosie O'Donnell who really doesn't have a professional career left.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CONTRIBUTOR: It's getting her attention, right?

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: But having said that, and he picked fights with her, so you could still say --

MCDOWELL: No, I said that there's a -- there's a mutual feud that's been going on for years.

HILSENRATH: But if someone had done this, something like this to Barack Obama, it would be universal outrage. There is a double standard. Regardless of their feud, there should be a certain respect for the presidency that she's not abiding by.

BARTIROMO: But again, I think people are tired of it, I don't know. Is it just me? I don't think people like to see a bloody head being held by Kathy Griffin and this game and the Shakespeare --

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: They see a lot of what goes on in this town as noise, it's just noise.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Kathy Griffin, though, the thing that was so appalling is that then she turns herself into the victim. And she makes it about her and she accused the Trump family of attacking her and trying to destroy her. That was the absurdity of it all.

SCHLAPP: I mean, it's just a constant pattern of the left, being so -- using these, I think, extreme displays of being critical of this president whether it's throwing him off the cliff, now it's a game, or, you know, using that image of the bloody beheading, and I just think they take it too far. And I think for Americans, it's kind of like he's the President of the United States, you might not agree with his policies, but let's be real, you know, there's no reason to be pushing this type of violence out there whether it's pushing him off a cliff.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: The liberals have been looking for attention.

BARTIROMO: The liberals has been, good comment. Yes.

HILSENRATH: That's all true. On the other side, you know, they're going to say, well, look at what he did with that WWE --

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: -- body-slamming the CNN character. So, it's not like he's tamping down the environment.

BARTIROMO: Well, he's going to fight back.

(CROSSTALK)

SCHLAPP: No, but that actually kind of funny.

MCDOWELL: It was -- it was a CNN logo on Vince McMahon's body from years ago. That's different than a direct obvious portrayal of a President who has been beheaded.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And CNN attacks him every day, by the way.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: They do. All right. We'll take a break. When we come back, Chipotle's stock dipping yesterday. Customers said they got sick from the food. Not again, details on the fast-food chain's illness report. That's next. Back in a minute, live from Washington this morning

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. More trouble for Chipotle. To tell you about it, Tracee Carrasco in New York with more on another Chipotle closure. Tracee, good morning to you.

TRACEE CARRASCO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Good morning, Maria. Yes, Chipotle is still trying to bounce back after an E. coli outbreak in 2015 that sickened hundreds of people in 14 states. And this incident is not helping. Chipotle was forced to temporarily close a restaurant in Sterling, Virginia, that's near Washington, D.C., after at least 13 customers reported getting sick from eating there, two people had to be hospitalized. Several customers reported their symptoms on the Web site, iwaspoisoned.com. Health officials say the symptoms are consistent with norovirus, which means the illness did not come from the food supply, so it is safe to eat at their other restaurants. Customers, though, aren't so sure.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I know they've had problems in the past, and it's very discouraging to hear that it's continuing on, so just disappointed. And I don't think we'll be back for a while.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARRASCO: Chipotle has dealt with norovirus cases in the past. In December of 2015, nearly 120 Boston College students got sick after a norovirus outbreak at a restaurant close to campus. The restaurant's stock price took a hit on Tuesday as news of the incident spread following more than 6.6 percent.

BARTIROMO: Well, there you go. I mean, there are real loyalists, though, to this company. I mean, some people, regardless of what happens, they keep going back. What has the company been doing since this last incident with -- to win back customers?

CARRASCO: You know, Maria, since the incident in 2015, Chipotle has appointed a senior officer in charge of food safety and implemented new procedures to help protect against contamination, but with the norovirus, you know, all it takes is one employee, for example, to not wash their hands, the norovirus can spread really quickly in places like daycares, nursing homes, schools, crew ships, restaurants. And this restaurant in Virginia was fully cleaned, expected to be back open. So, we'll see if customers will head back.

BARTIROMO: Norovirus.

MCDOWELL: When you have these -- when you have these mass outbreaks on cruise ships, when you have literally almost an entire ship gets sick, that's what it is, it's norovirus. It's the classic like stomach bug as my mother would describe it.

HILSENRATH: If this is coming from employees not washing hands, why doesn't it happen in other restaurants? Why does it keep happening on Chipotle?

BARTIROMO: That's a good point, Jon.

SCHLAPP: And I've been to Chipotle, they have their gloves on, too, normally, so I'm -- it's kind of interesting that would have some --

BARTIROMO: So, you're not buying the -- it's not from washing your hands?

MCDOWELL: It actually does happen in other restaurants that just doesn't get reported quite the same way it does because Chipotle had that huge E. coli outbreak. I think that these viruses do crop up. You can actually call the CDC.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- they're more in a fish bowl than other restaurants.

HILSENRATH: It's too bad for them because people were just starting to go back. I know my son had -- wasn't -- didn't go for a year and he was starting to get back into it. And now, we're going to have to look for someplace else.

BARTIROMO: We'll see about that. All right. We'll take a short break. We'll be right back. Thank you, Tracee Carrasco. Stay with us, live from D.C. this morning.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Live from Washington, D.C. here is Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, July 19th. Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Tax reform taking center stage. President Trump would --

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XP4-SSM1-DYTY-C09D-00000-00FROM HIPPY TECH BROS TO BIG BROTHER: HOW GOOGLE GOT A TOUCH OF EVIL;As its two founders step down, the web behemoth has a long charge sheet to answer, writes John Arlidge2019-12-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19FROM HIPPY TECH BROS TO BIG BROTHER: HOW GOOGLE GOT A TOUCH OF EVILAs its two founders step down, the web behemoth has a long charge sheet to answer, writes John ArlidgeJohn Arlidge

'Don't be evil" is the famous first line of Google's original code of conduct. It now seems like "a quaint relic of the company's early days, when the crayon colours of the Google logo still conveyed the cheerful, idealistic spirit of the enterprise. How long ago that feels." The opening of Rana Foroohar's new book, Don't Be Evil: The Case against Big Tech, is not only spot on, her timing is perfect: Sergey Brin and Larry Page announced last week that they were stepping down as leaders at Alphabet, parent company of Google, prompting many to question their record.

Critics say what started as a benign endeavour to organise information has turned into a corporate Big Brother.

The charge sheet is long but here are some of the worst sins: hoovering up our vast digital footprint and using it to serve targeted ads; abusing the dominance of its search platform to promote its services over those of rivals; slashing, legally, its tax bills by setting up overseas companies to funnel revenues into tax havens, and flogging ads to Russian agents, enabling them to manipulate the 2016 US presidential election.

Latterly, Brin and Page have been fighting their workers over Google's contracts with the US military and plans, now shelved, to create a search engine censored by Beijing. Last year, 20,000 Google staff walked out over sexual harassment, discrimination and pay inequality.

It was not always that way, as I found out in 2007 when I first saw the glass-and-steel curves of the Googleplex in Silicon Valley. Back then Brin and Page were in fine fettle.

They had convinced themselves and most of the world that they were not just shinier and smarter than the average entrepreneur, they were also better because they had a higher moral calling.

Google would never be like Microsoft, then the poster boy for monopolistic behaviour. As Page and Brin put it in 2004: "Google is not a conventional company. We do not intend to become one." When I raised privacy concerns, they said I'd got the wrong end of the memory stick. Not a single byte of my Google-generated data would ever be made available - far less flogged - to advertisers.

What went wrong? Why did digital utopians become rapacious, arrogant capitalists? Money.

Page and Brin soon realised their hippyish dream could be the best cash machine ever. Their firm now rakes in more than $100bn in advertising revenue a year, helping it to a market value close to $1trillion.

"Google has been the pioneer of big data, targeted advertising and surveillance capitalism," Foroohar says. "When Google advised its employees not to be evil, it did so because it knew that evil was more than a powerful temptation. Evil was baked into the business plan."

Google insists it uses "data to make our services more useful and to show relevant advertising, and we give people the controls to manage, delete or transfer their data". Critics are dismissive, claiming few people use them or even know they exist.

Until recently Brin and Page still pulled the wool over most people's eyes. It was not hard to see why. Google makes whizzy, free software, services we use every day, such as Gmail, Maps, Docs and Sheets. Android powers most smartphones.

But the penny has finally dropped. As techwriter Rob Cox puts it: "[Google has] the same profit motive that drives all business - and a ruthlessness rivalling history's greatest industrial bullies. " In her book, Foroohar lays the blame at Brin and Page's door but also says regulators have missed the point that we all "pay dearly with our data".

That is changing. The European Commission, which has already fined the company more than (EURO)8bn, last week launched a fresh investigation into Google.

Authorities on both sides of the Atlantic are trying to close tax loopholes.

Page and Brin have refused to engage with their critics. When you are worth more than $50bn each, you can get away with stuff like that.

Sundar Pichai, the new chief of Alphabet, will have no such luxury. "The next chapter is going to be a lot around policy, data privacy and regulation," points out Gene Munster, an analyst with Loup Ventures.

Or, to put it another way, Brin and Page leaving the Googleplex formally marks the end of the free-wheeling era in Silicon Valley.

Google founders Larry Page, left, and Sergey Brin convinced themselves they had a higher moral calling

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5R2H-T371-DXKP-J0TV-00000-00From net neutrality to digital privacy, Congress does diddly;And it's coming back to bite us.2017-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom net neutrality to digital privacy, Congress does diddlyAnd it's coming back to bite us.David Von Drehle

The Founding Fathers would be gobsmacked by an iPhone (although I bet Ben Franklin would catch on quickly). Yet if we asked them what branch of government should take the lead in adapting policy to a revolution in technology, they would say that's a job for Congress.

Alas, I reckon they would be gobsmacked by today's Congress, too. The august creation of Article I of the Constitution can't walk and chew gum at the same time. Often, Congress can't even walk. Gridlock in Congress stalls all causes: the bitterly divisive ones and the vital nonpartisan ones, too. The mobile digital age presents pressing issues, from privacy to the price of broadband. But Congress does, basically, diddly.

So the need for action falls to the executive branch and the courts - both of them problematic.

Relying on executive-branch regulators can result in radically shifting rules of the road. The Federal Communications Commission is a good example. Under Trump-appointed Chairman Ajit Pai, the FCC is preparing to reverse existing policy on "net neutrality," which requires that broadband providers treat all data equally. A change of presidents produces a screeching U-turn.

As for the courts, their limitations will be on display Wednesday in Washington, when the Supreme Court hears arguments over cellphone privacy. You might not realize that your cellular provider keeps track of your travels even when you have your GPS switched off. Each call, text, email and alert that enters or leaves your phone must pass through a nearby antenna.

In the case before the court, Timothy Carpenter's cellular provider supplied investigators a record of his smartphone's whereabouts. The pings placed Carpenter in the vicinity of several armed robberies in Ohio and Michigan. Now behind bars, he is asking the justices to find this a violation of his Fourth Amendment right to be safe from warrantless searches of his private domain.

Lower courts ruled that pre-iPhone case law was adequate to uphold Carpenter's conviction. Under existing law, if a person passes information through another entity - a "third party" such as a phone company or shipping firm - the fact of the transaction is not private. If you send a letter, for instance, the writing on the outside of the envelope can be read. If you dial a phone number, the fact of the call (though not its content) is information owned by the phone company. And the carrier can share that fact with police.

Carpenter's appeal is supported by big tech firms, leading civil liberties groups and digital privacy advocates. They argue that the transformative capabilities of the smartphone demand new protections against search and seizure of our personal digital property. If our entire lives - not just conversations but also shopping, studying, dating, navigating, playing, dining and documenting our experiences - take place with and through these devices, should all of it be public? Yet we have no choice but to use these increasingly indispensable tools.

Justice Sonia Sotomayor saw this issue coming. Writing in 2012, she found existing law "ill suited to the digital age, in which people reveal a great deal of information about themselves to third parties in the course of carrying out mundane tasks."

No doubt other justices share this insight. Judges are human, after all, and few humans with smartphones haven't fretted over the breadth and depth of the data collected by our digital overlords. And the problem doesn't stop with collection. The capacity to store nearly infinite amounts of data assures that our virtual trails will never go cold.

The need for new privacy protections seems clear. But in such an intricate web of issues, the courts aren't well suited to making policy. Their mandate is to decide the discrete legal questions presented one case at a time. A fully formed body of law from the bench may require decades of maturation through a series of cases.

Which brings us back to Congress - and, more hopefully, to state legislatures. The legislative branch is best equipped to define big issues, gather research, hold hearings, weigh competing interests and draft comprehensive reforms. Writing as a friend of the court in the Carpenter case, George Washington University law professor Orin Kerr, an authority on the Fourth Amendment and writer for the Volokh Conspiracy blog hosted by The Post, has urged the justices to restrain themselves. "The Court should continue to allow legislatures to debate and decide how much protection cell-site records should receive," Kerr asserted, pointing out that California recently passed very strict new privacy laws.

Partisan game-playing and mutual suspicion in Congress come at a high price. Pressing decisions that ought to be made by elected representatives in open deliberation are instead pushed into the cloistered chambers of the Supreme Court. Lawmakers claim to resent judges who legislate from the bench - but they're making it a last resort.

david.vondrehle@washpost.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V66-9WM1-JCBW-N061-00000-00FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT;The folk memory of Stasi, Nazi and Prussian snooping explains Germans' reticence to overshare on social media2019-01-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 29FROM OUR CORRESPONDENTThe folk memory of Stasi, Nazi and Prussian snooping explains Germans' reticence to overshare on social mediaOliver Moody

On the maps charting how Silicon Valley's tendrils of power have spread around the planet, one recalcitrant country stands out like Asterix's village in the landscape of Roman Gaul.

Germany is the developed world's last redoubt of resistance to social media. It is among a precious handful of rich countries whose people are more likely to buy a newspaper than follow current affairs on Twitter or Facebook. Scarcely two out of five Germans have a social network account, compared with two out of three Britons and Americans. It is not that they don't like the internet: more than 90 per cent of them are online, and they spend just as much time watching videos of skateboarding pugs, or browsing for remaindered shoes as their European neighbours. It is more that they are specifically reluctant to hawk out their lives for public consumption. My German friends' Facebook accounts are like a fleet of digital Mary Celestes. There might be a profile picture taken on a holiday in Sri Lanka six years ago and the odd status update wishing the world a happy new year, but that is more or less that.

The country's broader social networking culture is unusually stunted. A few dozen "influencers" - including Adrienne Koleszar, a blonde, gym-honed 34-year-old from Dresden who is fêted by the tabloids as "Germany's most gorgeous policewoman" - are fortunate enough to scrape a living together from their YouTube or Instagram accounts, but they are very much in the minority. The German Twittersphere is a niche habitat dominated by strange benthic fauna, such as political geeks, journalists, and right-wing obsessives.

Peter Mannion, a fictional Tory MP in the television political satire The Thick of It, has three times as many followers as the real-life German home secretary. Angela Merkel does not even have a presence. "If you look at how frequently Europeans use social networks, out of all 28 European Union member states the Germans are truly bottom of the pile," said Sabine Trepte, a media psychologist at Hohenheim University in Stuttgart. "Only a third of Germans look at Facebook on a daily basis," she notes, compared with about 60 per cent of internet users in the UK.

I used to have a small menagerie of pet theories on this subject. One: Germans pride themselves on their lack of small talk, which rules out pretty much 85 per cent of social media interactions. Two: big tech has built a business model the size of the Norwegian economy on Andy Warhol's insight that everyone will be famous for 15 minutes. Most people seem perfectly content to sacrifice their privacy in order to get a bit of attention. But perhaps the Germans are simply not that bothered.

Three: maybe they just don't care for being bossed around by evangelical Americans with big ideas.

Over dinner a couple of months ago, though, a German friend politely dismissed all this fanciful speculation. "Erm, I don't think so," she said. "It's actually because of the Stasi."

It was less than three decades ago that half the country was in the grip of a totalitarian surveillance state that maintained an informant for every seven ordinary people. The roots of Germany's itchy anxiety about being watched run deeper than that, though. Before the Stasi, there was the Gestapo. And even before the Gestapo, the Prussians riddled Berlin with a formidable network of secret police in the early 19th century.

"Perhaps it is really down to our past," Professor Trepte said. "The German fear of surveillance is deeply anchored in German history and in many families' sense of identity. You have to bear in mind that our mothers and fathers can still recall how they or other families were snooped on and persecuted. It was not all that long ago. First came the Nazis, then the Stasi. At the very least, the Germans are cautious and critical."

These ancient psychological scars have far-reaching consequences in the 21st century. Germany's privacy laws are among the strictest in the world.

With Berlin's blessing, the European Union's competition commissioner has become the only heavyweight regulator to take on Silicon Valley in earnest, imposing fines running to hundreds of millions of euros on previously untouchable companies such as Facebook, Google and Apple.

A year ago, Germany's ingrained wariness of social media might have seemed fusty and paranoid. But now, as the world wakes up to the many ways in which big tech has abused its power, it is starting to look prescient.

Adrienne Koleszar is one of Germany's few dozen social media "influencers"

A year ago, Germany's ingrained wariness of social media might have seemed fusty and paranoid. But now, as the world wakes up to the many ways in which big tech has abused its power, it is starting to look prescient.

Adrienne Koleszar is one of Germany's few dozen social media "influencers"

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5K5V-JFN1-F0J6-J4YV-00000-00From pariah to unlikely hero;COVER STORY2016-07-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisBOSSPg. 30From pariah to unlikely heroCOVER STORYNEIL CHENOWETH

Chris Jordan has transformed much of the way the tax office works. Just as importantly he has changed the way the ATO is perceived.

Chris Jordan's resolve crackles down the telephone from a car somewhere near Newcastle. Close to 80 of the 800 Australian names in the Panama Papers appear in the Australian Crime Commission's database for serious and organised crime, he reveals for the first time.

"And let me tell you, they're not there for not paying parking fines, these are serious criminals," he said.

It's April 11, seven days after the leak of documents from Panama law firm Mossack Fonseca, led by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, and it's difficult to imagine any of Australian Tax Commissioner Jordan's predecessors having this conversation.

"He cuts right to the point, that's why we love him," a regulator in another agency comments the following day. "It's also a learning curve for some."

In person Jordan is affable and engaged. In a series of interviews in the past two years it's clear that, while he doesn't really enjoy the media process, he's getting much better at it. He's feisty and he's indefatigable.

Three and a half years after he left his senior role at KPMG to lead the Australian Tax Office, Jordan has transformed much of the way the it works. Just as importantly he has changed the way the ATO is perceived.

It's easy to miss the scale of this change - and the change in institutional power it denotes.

The clearest sign came in April last year when Jordan was called before the Senate inquiry into corporate tax avoidance led by Labor senator Sam Dastyari. The script of such inquiries - really, any encounter between politicians and the tax office - usually writes itself. Because who likes the taxman?

The inquiry had been set up by the Greens after a Tax Justice Network report highlighted how many companies had no taxable income. And while senators would target multinationals such as Apple and Google, the real target was always likely to be the ATO and why it was failing.

Jordan clashed with Dastyari from the start.

Dastyari wanted Jordan to breach ATO secrecy rules to reveal names of big mining companies redacted from ATO documents and Jordan refused.

"I didn't think this was a precedent I wanted to have," Jordan said later.

Yet within days the political position had been completely reversed, with Jordan following up on his promise that, while he would not disclose taxpayer information, he would respond when he believed companies had misled the inquiry.

Jordan told the inquiry that claims by BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, Apple, Microsoft and Google that they were not profit shifting should not be taken at face value, revealing Rio paid more than $100 million to settle a tax bill while BHP subsequently revealed a $522 million tax bill. Jordan emerged from the inquiry as the man of the moment, not a whipping boy but rather an unlikely hero, in terms of public perception.

Since then politicians from both sides have sought his viewpoint, as he has expressed increasing resolve to pursue tax avoidance.

He is the government's point man on anything from multinationals to foreign property investors.

These are conversations that five years ago might have been led by the head of Treasury. And as Jordan's predecessor, Michael D'Ascenzo, is on the Foreign Investment Review Board, the tax office's input into government policy and regulation is increasing.

When Jordan became commissioner in January 2013 he inherited an organisation under pressure to cut costs as falling commodity prices eroded the revenue base, just as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development launched a historic attempt to rein in multinational tax avoidance (called Base Erosion Profit Shifting).

Jordan is a momentum player, a master of the front-foot response to a crisis. But he concedes that addressing the ATO's cost base was essential before anything else could be attempted.

By 2019 ATO staffing will be 23 per cent down from its peak in 2009, while its costs as a proportion of gross revenue collected are being slashed from 0.87 per cent in 2010 to 0.5 per cent in 2019.

In the last budget, the ATO received $679 million over four years to target tax avoidance by multinational companies and high-wealth individuals (it expects to raise $3.7 billion from this).

But at the end of the project, general funding will be down 23.5 per cent from 2014 in real terms.

Jordan also took a hard look at the legal cases the ATO was fighting and made some tough calls to settle many of them, while pursuing others - such as the successful Chevron transfer pricing case.

Jordan's success at Dastyari's tax inquiry wasn't a one-off. In October 2013, 10 months into the job, Jordan attended a meeting of the OECD's Forum on Tax Administration (FTA) and proposed an international collaboration to target big tech companies, including Apple and Google.

Jordan led a six-country investigation that set up new protocols to share information - a project that US officials opposed after lobbying by US tech companies. Australia was halfway through a tax amnesty program, Project Do It, in October 2014 when the ICIJ revealed LuxLeaks - the leak of hundreds of secret tax deals by the Luxembourg government.

Jordan immediately wrote to tax commissioners around the world to organise a coordinated response to the revelations.

When the Panama Paper story broke on April 2 this year, Jordan was immediately on the front foot, revealing that more than 800 Australians on earlier Mossack Fonseca lists were under investigation.

Four days later he used his position as chairman of the FTA's working body, the Joint International Tax Shelter Information and Collaboration Network, to call a meeting of tax officials from 35 countries to share information and coordinate a response to the Mossack Fonseca documents.

That's how he came to be giving an interview on April 11 about the links of Panama Papers-named Australians to serious crime. The task force that was set up in Paris the next day was a scaled-up version of his earlier model to target tech companies.

Before the Senate Estimates Committee in February, Jordan gave his extraordinarily blunt "enough is enough" speech.

"The excuses we sometimes hear from these companies are, frankly, over the top," he said, appearing to refer to tech companies and other big corporates.

"Their clear tactic is to delay and obstruct. They game the system ... These companies have pushed the envelope on reasonableness. They play games.

They string us along. They believe we can be stooged.

However, enough is enough and no more of this."

It's a message that resonates across both sides of politics, feeding into a worldwide public response against multinational companies that pay no tax.

"I will not stand by and admire the problem," Jordan told a hastily reconvened tax inquiry last month.

In this age of regulators, Jordan is not just on to it.

He's disappearing around the corner.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SD5-CCP1-DYFH-V1HT-00000-00From 'patient' to 'consumer'2018-05-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisPg. 18From 'patient' to 'consumer'Rachel Z. Arndt

The word "patient" is rapidly fading from the healthcare lexicon. Nowadays, healthcare executives sound like those from any other industry, talking about "consumers" or even "customers."

With consumer-friendly companies like Apple and Amazon nipping at the heels of traditional healthcare organizations, not to mention the rise in out-of-pocket expenses, the consumer is inching toward center stage in healthcare. Leaders are responding with efforts to create more seamless and convenient healthcare experiences. They're starting to notice that consumerism matters. That's reflected in how they're using technology, innovative thinking and hiring. Healthcare CEOs see consumerism transforming the industry and are looking for tools to navigate that change, according to Modern Healthcare's most recent Power Panel survey of 75 top CEOs.

But saying an organization is consumer-focused isn't enough. It's about executing a real strategy, whether that's driving patients to lower-acuity settings or turning mobile devices into health management tools. In general, the CEOs saw investment in technology and new ways of conducting their business speeding up, with none saying that innovation is slowing down and only a few saying that it's staying the same.

Catering to consumers

"Consumerism is playing a major role in innovation as we see more and more lower-acuity care options go digital or go to lower acuity settings, such as urgent care," said Ochsner Health System CEO Warner Thomas.

One of those digital options is telemedicine. As reimbursement opportunities grow and consumers learn to shop more effectively for care, virtual interactions with the healthcare system are becoming more common. Medicare fee-for-service telemedicine volume has been on the rise, with coding instances up 28% between 2015 and 2016. Medicare Part B telehealth reimbursements totaled $28.7 million in 2016 .

"It's been a huge opportunity for us in care delivery to minimize the amount of travel and the out-of-pocket costs," Marshfield Clinic Health System CEO Dr. Susan Turney said. The Marshfield health plan covers telemedicine services, and Turney expects other insurers will soon do the same. "We all know that a hospital is an expensive place to provide care," she said.

The move to more virtual care goes hand in hand with the rise of mobile devices. Many patients now want to receive care via those devices, Turney said.

More than two-thirds of survey respondents said mobile devices have the most potential of various technologies to drive innovation in the next year. And just under half said telehealth will drive innovation the most.

Meanwhile, healthcare organizations are starting to compete with consumer giants. Apple launched a new version of its Health app early this year that lets patients of certain providers download their health records to their iPhones. And just before that, Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase announced they're teaming up to form a healthcare company, although few details have emerged.

Amazon also recently hired a former Food and Drug Administration chief health informatics officer to work on healthcare business development. And then there's continued push from retail clinics like CVS Health and Walgreens further into the traditional provider space.

"When you have new entrants into the market that are known for their disruption and innovation, and have virtually zero limitations from a resource perspective, you have to take notice," Turney said. "I think it's exciting. I think we're going to see changes."

Inching towards AI

One consumer tech company that's been noticeably quieter in healthcare is Alphabet, though the company, which became Google's parent company in 2015 through a corporate restructuring, is poised to make a splash with artificial intelligence. The company's DeepMind AI subsidiary has been working on detecting kidney injuries, for instance, and its data analytics subsidiary Verily is developing algorithmic retinopathy detection.

"The next wave of innovation around AI and predictive analytics is going to be very powerful in its impact on the healthcare industry," Ochsner's Thomas said.

In general, AI is just as promising as telehealth, according to the respondents, just under half of whom said AI has the most potential to drive innovation in the coming year. Nearly one-third also called AI integration into electronic health records the most innovative development of the past year, putting it in front of giving patients ways to aggregate their own medical data (25%), the Veterans Affairs and Defense departments' push for interoperability (2.8%), and the CMS' MyHealthEData initiative (0%).

"I don't think AI is something for the future-it's happening today," Thomas said. "Its impact and scale will increase in the future." His organization is using AI to predict patient deterioration in some units outside of intensive care. During a pilot program in those units, there's been a 44% reduction in adverse events.

"With all the information we have in our EHR, and with more and more information about our patients, the ability to be much more predictive is a reality," Thomas said.

Other health systems aren't as far along, but they're still beginning to tap AI for its predictive powers. "We're just scratching the surface of what opportunity exists for AI," Turney said. Marshfield has some machine-learning-based clinical decision-support tools.

Driving innovation from the inside ...

The majority of respondents said their boards regularly discuss innovation, and the majority also have an executive in charge of innovation. Reporting structures vary, with 8% reporting to the chief operating officer and 36% to the CEO, according to a recent survey of chief innovation officers at the 40 largest healthcare systems by revenue in the U.S.

Though 83% of respondents to Modern Healthcare's survey said they saw innovation picking up over the past year, there are still barriers-namely, culture, which 69% cited as the biggest threat or challenge to innovation.

"Having someone responsible for innovation in one's organization is very important, but it's really a multifaceted, multidisciplinary approach that's needed," Turney said.

Some organizations get stuck in their ways because that's more comfortable, said Cambia Health Solutions CEO Mark Ganz. " 'We had a great year last year' is one of the big excuses," he said. "Frankly, it's hard. It gets really scary when you get to your actual revenue model and the path forward tells you that you have to put that at risk to make the leap." That's why, he added, innovation often sounds a lot bigger than it turns out to be.

To make truly important innovations, health systems must listen to their customers, Ganz said. They must do what Uber and Lyft have done and figure out what consumers can't even articulate wanting. "The only real way to understand what consumers want is to go into the field and ask them directly," he said.

They might also look beyond digital tools alone, said Indiana University Health CEO Dennis Murphy. "Everybody thinks the only way you can innovate is to have some technological advance," he said. "We're finding a lot of innovations can occur without the use of technology but with changing the team and changing the thinking."

... and from the outside

Besides culture, respondents also said federal regulations are getting in the way of innovation. But that doesn't mean the government can't help, some respondents said.

"The government can play a huge role by creating financial incentives to develop and adopt digital solutions," Turney said. "The government can really help us strike a balance of not encumbering innovation but still maintaining a very safe environment."

Half of the respondents agreed with her, saying that the best way for the government to encourage digital innovation is to offer financial incentives to develop and use digital tools. It's already done that, notably with the EHR incentive program, which paid out more than $30 billion to Medicare and Medicaid providers for adopting electronic record systems.

But half the respondents also said that federal regulations are the biggest threat or challenge to innovation.

For example, though Medicare recently expanded coverage for virtual visits, there's been slow progress in getting Medicare to pay for more telemedicine services, said Cathy Jacobson, CEO of Froedtert and the Medical College of Wisconsin. "The government's role is to remove the barriers," she said.

The federal government might also help by setting standards, such as uniform insurance and billing forms, Jacobson said, as well as other technical standards. "We still have EHRs that can't talk to each other because we haven't set the standards to make that happen," she said.

Which brings things back to consumer technology companies. "You are going to see the big tech companies get some way for patients to own and house their own records," she said. "They're going to do that no matter what."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TMG-CJ21-JCDN-10TC-00000-00From pharma to prisons, election-sensitive stocks that could swing2018-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisBUSINESSFrom pharma to prisons, election-sensitive stocks that could swing

NEW YORK: Tuesday's midterm U.S. congressional elections stand to have broad effects on federal government policies that could ripple through industries from healthcare and tech to gunmakers and prisons. Investors are bracing for a split Congress, with Democrats taking control of the House of Representatives and Republicans holding their advantage in the Senate, but are mindful that President Donald Trump's victory in 2016 surprised experts. Taking a majority in even one of the chambers in the Nov. 6 elections would give Democrats a chance to more effectively oppose the Republican president's agenda.

With tech leading the way in the Wall Street rally since Trump's victory, here is a look at policies and stocks the elections should put in focus: GRAPHIC: Soaring stock sectors since Trump elected - https://tmsnrt.rs/2P1Gm9n HEALTHCARE POLICY: Perhaps no sector will be in the election spotlight as much as healthcare, which has been one of the top-performing S&P 500 sectors this year. Policy efforts to lower prescription drug prices that have started under Trump could get more attention should Democrats gain control in Congress. Democratic gains in particular could lead investors to anticipate expanded coverage or other changes related to the Affordable Care Act, possibly benefiting some insurer company and hospital shares. Stocks to watch: Merck , AbbVie , Amgen , Mylan , CVS Health , Anthem , Centene , HCA Healthcare , Tenet Healthcare GRAPHIC: Healthcare's run, from election to election - https://tmsnrt.rs/2CQkHtn TRADE: Concerns over trade tensions between the United States and other countries, especially China, have roughed up manufacturers and other companies that depend on international markets, weighing in particular on the industrial sector. One way the elections could be a factor: Trump's newly forged pact with Canada and Mexico is not expected to be voted on until after the new Congress is seated in January, and there remains a possibility that it will not be approved if Democrats gain control of the House. "We think headline risk is likely in early 2019 around possible NAFTA withdrawal that will be harmful to industries dependent on open trade across North America," according to Height Capital Markets. Stocks to watch: Caterpillar , Boeing , Ford , General Motors , Bunge , DowDuPont INFRASTRUCTURE: A boost in federal infrastructure spending on bridges, roads and other projects is one Trump agenda item seen as an initiative that Democrats potentially could support, should the two sides seek common ground in the event of Democratic gains in Congress, potentially boosting construction and materials stocks. The Democrats will have to balance the benefits of a real boost to infrastructure spending and the political risks of giving the president a win on that, said Christopher Smart, head of macroeconomic and geopolitical research at Barings. Stocks to watch: Granite Construction , Fluor , Nucor , Martin Marietta Materials TECH AND TELECOM OVERSIGHT: Scrutiny on Big Tech over antitrust and data privacy issues could pick up with Democrats leading the House, although "we do not foresee this scrutiny translating into actual policy," according to Height Capital Markets. That could spell more volatility for tech stocks, which have been the best performing sector since Trump's election but have been battered in recent weeks. "We see the Democratic party no longer as the unconditional defender of the tech sector," Capital Alpha Partners said in a September report. Height Capital analysts also see "headline risk" for telecom companies from any efforts by the House to address regulations related to equality on the internet, known as "net neutrality," although the analysts see little risk of policy change if the Senate stays Republican. Stocks to watch: Alphabet , Facebook , Amazon , Twitter , Verizon , AT&T GRAPHIC: Taking stock of industry performance since Trump - https://tmsnrt.rs/2OZZQuR REGULATION: If Republicans maintain their hold on both chambers of Congress, or perhaps expand their advantage, that could lift investors' hopes for further deregulation of the financial industry and give a boost to stocks. With Democratic gains, "headline risk for the banking industry would significantly increase as we anticipate numerous congressional hearings," according to analysts at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Stocks to watch: JP Morgan , Wells Fargo , Goldman Sachs DEFENSE: Spending on national defense is one area that could come into focus for potential federal cuts, especially if Democrats make strong gains. "A Republican surprise might well be helpful for defense stocks in the near term," said Smart of Barings, adding that the near-term "expectation will be more tax cuts and fewer defense cuts." Stocks to watch: Lockheed Martin , Raytheon , Northrop Grumman , General Dynamics IMMIGRATION: Should Republicans hold control of Congress, that could create expectations for harsher federal policies on immigration. Such policies would also spark expectations for expansion of demand for detention center space, potentially helping to fill prison operators' idle facilities or even generating the need for new ones. Stocks to watch: CoreCivic , Geo Group GUN CONTROL: Democratic gains in Congress could pave the way for calls for more stringent legislation to control gun sales. But the prospect of stricter regulations on the firearms industry, paradoxically, could drive up shares of gun-makers. Investors in the past have bid up shares of gun companies in anticipation of tougher rules, because investors predict gun owners will hurry to buy more firearms if they worry about impending restrictions. Indeed, gun stocks have struggled since Trump's election, a time in which control of Congress and the federal government has been held by Republicans, who are seen as resistant to stricter laws. Stocks to watch: American Outdoor Brands , Sturm Ruger & Co GRAPHIC: Since Trump: Prison stocks soar, gunmakers struggle - https://tmsnrt.rs/2CUGosn GRAPHIC: Interactive graphic: sector performance since Trump's election - https://tmsnrt.rs/2OZZQuR GRAPHIC: Interactive graphic: sector performance since Trump's election - https://tmsnrt.rs/2PzLReG (Reporting by Lewis Krauskopf in New York; Additional reporting by Sinead Carew in New York and Noel Randewich in San Francisco; Editing by Leslie Adler) - Reuters

urn:contentItem:5Y86-JMF1-F05M-K456-00000-00From the editor: A rather important message to pass along to Silicon Valley2020-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom the editor: A rather important message to pass along to Silicon ValleyJ. Jennings Moss

It can be easy for Silicon Valley to feel a little brought down, at least when it comes to how outsiders sees this slice of the world.

The Democrats running for president either want to break up Big Tech or beef up government regulations, or both. The only time President Donald Trump seems to offer praise to the Valley is when tech giants hit the trillion-dollar valuation mark. As for the average Joe or Joanne, they like their tech, but fewer of them really trust the companies that make it.

Leave it, then, to a veteran journalist to come to town and give Silicon Valley business, community and government leaders a pep talk.

"Technology is a tool, of course," Dan Rather said at the annual State of the Valley conference on February 14. Rather went on to say that the Valley had created "the most powerful tools ever imagined by the human mind. They can and must be harnessed for good. And, yes, I believe you are the ones who can do it."

Rather, the 88-year-old newsman best known for succeeding Walter Cronkite as anchor of CBS Evening News, avoided making direct references to Trump or any of the people running to replace him. But he did make it clear how he felt about today's political climate.

"I see a deep danger in our current leadership. I do not consider this to be a strictly political judgment. We can and should debate our tax policies. We can and should debate how we structure healthcare and our regulatory system. That's the American way. But we shouldn't debate hard facts and truth," Rather said, taking aim at corruption, climate crisis-deniers and hardline voices against immigration.

Rather described this time period as "chaotic and uncertain, a moment of great challenge and risk ... And the truth is, that the world has serious problems and that technology of Silicon Valley has helped to contribute to some of that, and even more importantly, can help also to be a solution."

A social media star in his own right - he has 873,000 followers on Twitter and 76,500 followers on Instagram - Rather said he's realized that technology advances far faster than humans do.

"The way we share information has elements that are unlocking dreams and talent, but other elements that are spreading dangerous propaganda," he said, sending a specific message to journalists and media companies.

For Silicon Valley, Rather said he still saw "sunny optimism and idealism, a belief - a deep belief - that technology can improve the human condition." But he also said we need to remind ourselves that while change is an integral part of the American experience, "we're not great at everything."

"Silicon Valley should be a place that shows the promise of science and data and dreaming big. It should be a place that understands its disruptive role and seeks to disrupt that which needs to be disrupted, while protecting the core values like diversity and truth," he said. "I submit to you that the Silicon Valley must be a place of hope. The nation turns to you, yes still turns to you, not just to distract and entertain, but to enlighten and to inform."

For a time in 1986, five years into his 24-year run leading CBS' main newscast, Rather ended the program with an odd sign off. It was a single word, "courage," and it was widely mocked. Needless to say, it didn't last long.

Yet, I think that's the message Rather tried to impart to Silicon Valley during his Valentine's Day speech. We need to have courage to keep innovating. We need to have courage to admit when we've gone too far. And, as Rather paraphrased the journalist H.L. Mencken, we need to have courage to fight against "ignorance, intolerance and indifference."

urn:contentItem:5V2D-VCC1-F05M-K0MW-00000-00From the editor: Five stories to watch for 2019;The new year keeps up the heat on big tech, outward migration and recession fears as it opens up to the dawn of 5G and Silicon Valley tests of autonomous vehicles.2018-12-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom the editor: Five stories to watch for 2019The new year keeps up the heat on big tech, outward migration and recession fears as it opens up to the dawn of 5G and Silicon Valley tests of autonomous vehicles.J. Jennings Moss

With 2018 just about in the rearview mirror, it's time to look ahead and make some predictions about what 2019 has in store for Silicon Valley. Here are my picks for the story lines to watch in the coming year.

The war on Big Tech gets real: Don't count on the scrutiny surrounding the tech industry - especially the influence and tactics of social media - to ease up. In fact, watch for Congress to get even more aggressive with its questioning of Facebook, Inc., Google, Twitter, Inc. and others. Democrats, who will control the House in the next Congress, may not care about Republican claims of political bias, but they do care about continued reports that users' privacy is being invaded. Forcing these companies to become public utilities, as some have suggested, likely won't become a serious effort but legislation restricting what information they can share with third parties is a real possibility. It might just be one of the few things House Democrats, Senate Republicans and the Trump administration can agree on.

Driverless cars become a real presence on Silicon Valley streets: Alphabet Inc.-owned Waymo, which secured the first driverless vehicle permit in California in October, should start to test cars in Mountain View, Sunnyvale, Los Altos, Los Altos Hills and Palo Alto. Waymo won't be the only such cars on the road: In the second half of 2019, Mercedes-Benz models will hit the streets in San Jose as part of a mostly autonomous taxi service that's a trial program between Mercedes owner Daimler AG, German tech company Bosch and the city of San Jose. They'll give us all a real-world look at an industry that's become one of the Valley's more innovative economic drivers.

The 5G era begins: For the last several years, we've been told far and wide that 5G is coming. In 2019, the fifth generation of mobile cellular tech arrives. The city of San Jose has made adoption of 5G a key part of its smart city efforts. AT&T will be the first major provider to bring 5G to the region and has said it would start the service in both San Jose and San Francisco in the first part of the new year. Pushing all the hype aside, will this new tech be a game changer? According to most experts, the answer is a clear yes: The global impact of 5G technology will hit $12 trillion by 2035. That kind of money will have a big influence on work done here for autonomous cars, artificial intelligence, virtual and augmented reality, and more.

The economy will stumble: We're already seeing signs of a national economic slowdown, and that's all but guaranteed to continue in the new year. The word "recession" is getting thrown around right and left, with many economists believing we'll fall into one in 2019. That kind of a correction after the heavy gains the economy has sustained over the last several years is natural. The real question is how long and how hard will it be. The good news is that we're not looking at the kind of dot-com bust that shook Silicon Valley to its core nearly two decades ago or the Great Recession that smacked the entire country a decade ago. One other positive note: A new report from Oxford Economics says San Jose will have the fastest-growing economy in the United States through 2035.

Outward migration keeps moving on: One of the big story lines of 2018 was that some companies and people had enough with the Bay Area and were leaving, not just the region, but the state. This outward migration trend will only continue in the new year as housing stock hasn't kept up with demand, housing prices remain oppressive, repressive business regulation is an ongoing challenge and a push to add new taxes to companies will have a few of them thinking either of relocating entirely or establishing more satellite offices. We're not yet at a tipping point where this should be a major cause for concern, but if any of the region's corporate giants were to decide they were finished here, the narrative would quickly change.

urn:contentItem:5PGN-3V81-JCPJ-W3WD-00000-00From the editor: Watch out, tech giants - it's regulation time2017-09-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom the editor: Watch out, tech giants - it's regulation timeJ. Jennings Moss

The tech industry - and Silicon Valley's dominant role as the home base of some of the biggest and most powerful companies in the world - is under attack. And this has nothing to do with Apple coming out with a new iPhone that will set back the iOS-minded a cool grand.

Over the past week, there's been a stream of stories calling out the Valley's biggest employers as being monopolies engaged in unfair business behavior, or trying to stifle free speech, or helping promote "fake news." And this all comes on the heels of revelations of sexual harassment or misconduct at high-profile companies and among high-powered investors.

Join the conversation: Follow@SVbizjournalon Twitter, "Like" us on   Facebookand   sign up for our free email newsletters.

None of this is exactly new: Ever since Donald Trump moved into the White House, replacing the very tech-friendly Barack Obama and angering much of the industry's ruling class, things have been frosty. What is different is that Silicon Valley is getting hit from all sides now. Just look at these headlines, all of which were published this week, and you'll see a trend:

" Conservatives, liberals unite against Silicon Valley" - Politico

" There's blood in the water in Silicon Valley" - BuzzFeed

" How Silicon Valley is erasing your individuality" - The Washington Post

And the piling on isn't just happening on home turf. Here's a headline from the U.K.-based The Telegraph - "Government signals end to 'tech utopia' for Silicon Valley giants"- with the government in question being that of British Prime Minister Theresa May.

Several factors are at play for this anti-Valley hostility, not the least of which are critics in the media. Tucker Carlson, the Fox News prime time host who also runs the conservative news site the Daily Caller, is on a crusade to treat Google as a public utility. Normally one who abhors government regulation of business, Carlson openly is calling for Washington to step in and regulate this one company.

"Google seems to be letting politics dictate who is allowed to make money from their platform," Carlson charged during one Fox News broadcast last week.

Plenty of people in the Valley will no doubt brush off Carlson as just another right-wing pundit angry at the tech industry's liberal political tendencies. But these are the same people who should be concerned about another media voice that's harder for them to dismiss - Franklin Foer, a staff writer for the The Atlantic and a former New Republic editor-in-chief who has written the new book " World Without Mind: The Existential Threat of Big Tech."

"It's hard not to marvel at these companies and their inventions, which often make life infinitely easier," Foer wrote in a column in The Washington Post (the one with the "erasing your individuality" headline mentioned above.) "But we've spent too long marveling. The time has arrived to consider the consequences of these monopolies, to reassert our role in determining the human path."

Tech giants don't like to think of themselves as monopolies. They prefer to cast themselves as dynamic, multifaceted corporations aimed at making our lives more productive and entertaining. But they're also highly competitive, acquiring smaller startups that have technology they covet and becoming aggressive competitors against bigger companies that operate in a sliver of their universe.

If they haven't already, these Silicon Valley powerhouses should start preparing for an aggressive push from a Washington administration that loathes regulations and a media landscape that's starting to seriously question how they do business.

urn:contentItem:5N88-9RR1-JCPJ-W4PM-00000-00From the editor: What equal pay needs to become reality2017-04-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:15ZLexisNexisFrom the editor: What equal pay needs to become realityJ. Jennings Moss

This past Tuesday came the 21st commemoration of Equal Pay Day, a date that shifts to reflect how far into a new year women must work to earn what men made the previous year. It's unfortunate that in 2017, it takes women five fiscal quarters to earn what men make in four.

The detailed stats on this are distressing. The 20 percent, on average, pay gap between the sexes gets worse as you factor in elements of race and ethnicity.

Join the conversation: Follow@SVbizjournalon Twitter, "Like" us on   Facebookand   sign up for our free email newsletters.

Perhaps the most unsettling part is that this remains a big story. Yes, it's gotten better over the years - in 1980, women made about 60 percent of what men made. But couldn't the disparity have been wiped out over more than three decades?

Some politicians have tried to get government involved. The first piece of legislation former President Barack Obama signed into law was the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009 that made it easier to file equal pay lawsuits.

In contrast, President Donald Trump last week revoked an Obama executive order from 2014 that, in part, helped women who worked for federal contractors in pay matters. Trump has said he believes in equal pay for equal work, though he's also on a crusade to reduce government regulations on business.

The involvement of Washington lawmakers wouldn't be needed if corporate executives and business owners would do one simple thing - commit to fixing the imbalance.

A number of big tech companies - Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft - last year reported they had achieved near-parity on pay. At Apple, for example, CEO Tim Cook said female employees made 99.6 cents for every dollar a male employee made.

This week, Salesforce spent $3 million to help close the wage gap in its workforce. It spent the same amount last year.

"The need for another adjustment underscores the nature of pay equity - it is a moving target, especially for growing companies in competitive industries. It must be consistently monitored and addressed," Salesforce executive vice president Cindy Robbins said in a statement.

Yes, this is good PR for companies. But more importantly, it's absolutely the right action to take. Every CEO, COO, CFO, and human resources VP needs to go through their company's payroll numbers, find where the disparities occur and fix them.

If that happens, then maybe in 2018, Equal Pay Day will fall sometime in March. And perhaps, if there's real executive leadership, Equal Pay Day will disappear long before 2152 - the year analysts predict the gap will disappear.

Graphic: How men and women differ in paycheck equality

A series of recent studies show the depth of the wage gap.

In one analysis from the Silicon Valley Institute for Regional Studies, women earned 74 cents for every dollar a man made, according to 2015 data. That was the same as the national figure, but worse than either San Francisco's 77 cents or California's 79 cents. One disturbing footnote: The higher degree of education a woman had, the greater disparity.

Hired.com explored the wage issue a couple of other ways. Rather than just looking at the male-female gap, it also factored in race and ethnicity. White, Asian and Latino men earned more than all women, but white women earned more than black men and black women trailed everyone.

Check out the graphic for more data from Hired.com that looks at what happens when men and women ask employers for more money.
